evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Large firm, so you get to be involved with a lot of different types of projects. There are a lot of opportunities to learn as an entry level professional.
Cons: I have been working at the WSP NYC office for over 5 years. I enjoyed the first few years but things have gone downhill quickly in the last few months. The new management team is solely focused on profitability. We are being asked to meet unrealistic goals, creating a very toxic environment. There have been several rounds of layoffs from entry level professionals to senior managers over the last few months. Each Friday, people are afraid of bad news. Employees are treated as if they are disposable.
Advice to Management: Refocus on what a consulting firm is about, it's people.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Size of company. When you get fed up with the same report/meetings 5 times a week, you can go work for another group and have different talking points at the same mundane meetings until you get bored of them too...
Cons: All of their "benefits" they keep promoting are for their P11's *upper management* and higher. "Oh well if employee contributed their max, they would save more"... yeah. if you didn't slash our salary by 30%, maybe i could afford to contribute more....
Advice to Management: I don't care about your media wins, progress reports, and "just checking in" 5 times a week. You cut our salary by 30%, cut our staff by 27%, and wonder why our productivity tanked. If you expect me to overperform, then quit with the all the extra BS. Forcing us to attend these meetings to stroke your ego's and these "lunch and learns"... you all keep buying out these other companies and all you're doing is buying them out of their debt and tanking our brand. Well done.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Staff and coworkers are wonderful Variety of projects and national presence Opportunities for advancement if you are assertive.
Cons: Reorganization has crippled staff Raises and bonuses are not tied to performance  Management lacks direction or focus
Advice to Management: Stop buying debt-laden firms for pennies on the dollar as fake “growth” - the rest of us have to increase productivity beyond normal human levels to make up for the shortcomings of the terrible decisions made by Louis Berger, E&E, Golder, or whatever next dying firm you buy.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: Very healthy corporate culture, I was always given the tools I needed to complete a task, and encouraged to ask questions when necessary. They tried to expose me to many different areas instead of pigeonholing me in menial work, which can sometimes happen with internships. Pay was also very good, $20 an hour.
Cons: There were times when there just wasn't enough work, and as the intern, you are the last to be fed, so to speak. So there were days where I'd just be sitting at my desk plugging through tutorials because there was nothing else to do.
Advice to Management: I was honestly really impressed by WSP. Maybe offer more ways for interns to connect with each other? I worked with one other intern in my office, but having access to interns in other disciplines could be valuable.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The best aspects of working here were the flexible hours and the office amenities. As someone who decidedly falls outside of the "morning person" category, I very much appreciated the ability to schedule my mandated 40 hours a week in any way I chose within office hours (6am to 10pm if I remember correctly) to a maximum of 10 hours a day. My location in Aurora, Colorado was somewhat secure, with employee badges used for entry at one of two entry points. Free coffee and tea, with the occasional pizza party or similar food-centric encouragement mechanism. There is large break room for the building, with 2 large fridge/freezer combos for use by employees as well as vending machines for snacks and beverages, 6 microwaves, a TV, and a variety of comfortable seating options. There is a small fitness center available to employees with two bathrooms, each with their own shower. You can claim a locker if needed. Water fountains were fitted with the extension that quickly fills water bottles. You are free to use approved mp3 players and headphones in accordance with certain regulatory guidelines (typically a device that lacks any sort of receiving or recording capability will be approved). There is a generous training period of about a month. The human resources department seemed to genuinely care about the well-being of employees and were very helpful. Employees could use the e-470 toll road and receive rebates to offset the tolls. Openings in other positions within the company were always emailed to all employees, so advancement or lateral moves are available occasionally.
Cons: The biggest issue I have is with the company policy of hiring temporary workers and keeping them on temporary status permanently. I was hired on a 3 month contract, and at the end of my contract, my direct supervisor spent all of 2 minutes to tell me to keep coming to work. This was in line with the usual supervisor interactions being short and stinted with no room for discussion. I thought I was being moved to full-time employment, but I was never afforded the benefits and compensation thereof. This means no health insurance, no 401k, no PTO, no vacation days, no health insurance, and so on. Temporary workers do accrue TTO, though its accrual is at a much slower pace than full-time employees' PTO accrual. However, this TTO must be used to cover any absence, so a single sick day can wipe out a month or more of TTO accrual. Time on the clock is heavily metered. You are allotted 5 minutes of paid break time within an hour of work, and an unpaid lunch of a minimum 30 minute duration you can place at any point in the day, so long as you don't work more than 5.5 hours consecutively. In addition, any activity that has you leave your computer was to be preceded by you clocking out on break and locking your computer, meaning that precious break time was often chipped away by office errands, bathroom breaks, and trips to the water fountain or coffee machine, with no real chance to disconnect and refresh, resulting in every day being more of a slog than any other job I've had. The rebate for the toll road usage is incredibly micro managed to the point where the company will tell you exactly where you can enter and exit the toll road while still qualifying for the rebate. There is also the oddity that you have to first pay the regular toll rate, and file a separate claim for the rebate each separate month.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: I worked on a wide variety of projects across the USA in the 2-3 years that I worked for WSP.   Project managers generally do a great job of supporting younger staff and set an excellent example of how to produce quality work.
Cons: Travel is constant. I typically traveled 30 to 35 weeks a year.   The environmental group is overly reliant on one long term customer. This has led to complacency in that group and most of the senior staff are completely incapable of business development.  Health insurance is expensive and 301K match is somewhat weak.
Advice to Management: Pay performance bonuses to junior staff.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Some really good people work(ed) there; Working remotely during pandemic was implemented smoothly; Flexibility in work hours; Business casual dress code.
Cons: Very top-heavy management, with many not qualified for the responsibilities that accompany position; Sr. management filled with people who are only interested in how far they can climb and promote "yes men". Bonuses and other perks only for management and above positions; Company is solely focused on money, with no regard to employees - Corporate is penny wise and pound foolish; Corporate has no clue how to effectively run certain divisions - they try to mold them into their core business, which doesn't work. Employees are stretched thin due to layoffs of non-billable staff, constant "restructuring", and are extremely stressed and demoralized. Being billable is the only thing that senior management and corporate are concerned about.
Advice to Management: Corporate - Actually visit every division and find out what they do and how things actually work. Stop restructuring every time the wind blows. Make an attempt to value your employees - even those who work to make the business function but are not always billable. Vet your picks for senior level management more thoroughly. You are bleeding out on the talent front because of your out of touch antics , push to make bigger profits, and lack of caring for the very employees that make your business successful.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: WSP USA is a large firm with a really wide range of projects in every aspect of infrastructure development, from planning and finance to design and permitting. This provides staff with an exciting mix of project opportunities that great for younger staff gaining experience. As a young staff member, you have endless opportunities to pursue your interests. You also have tremendous flexibility to work in other cities and countries, as WSP has locations throughout the world.
Cons: PTO and health benefits for younger staff are not as good as in comparable companies.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Since the new CEO has taken the reigns of this company, it has done a complete 180. I have been working here for years, back when it was Parsons Brinckerhoff and although my situation has been a good one, I see why others had issues. There was a lot of things done behind the scenes and decisions that were made based on bottom line and not employee based. I feel that this company has now come into the 21st century with a leadership team that has worked together to be transparent, diverse and have the best communication with the employees. They listened to feedback and made changes based on that. Their handling of the COVID situation has been second to none. I could never be happier than I am now working for this company. I look forward to many more years to come.
Cons: Since the new regime, I have NOTHING bad to say.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing. You are all a breathe of fresh air and I am super lucky to have been here to see it.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Decent work culture (great company events, happy hour Fridays, and general camaraderie, though I've heard this has changed under new management) Training (some companies don't offer training) Great benefits (health, 401K, sick leave) Summer Fridays CSA shares offered to employees (freshly delivered fruit & vegetables for cheap prices)
Cons: Office Politics & nepotism from management Age discrimination (pushing out older workers) Lack of communication Company culture not as good as it once was due to trying to impress new management Unclear responsibilities and not giving new emloyees a chance to prove their worth
Advice to Management: Don't treat people like cogs in a machine. Give employees growth opportunities and communicate with them early on if there is a problem; treat people like adults and make expectations and HR situations clear from the get-go. DOn't leave new employees out of the loop and have private meetings they are not privy to and them blame them for 'not participating'. Don't hire and choose to keep people based on their age or who they are related to at the company; value employees based on merit. Do not give the best and most complicated work to interns and inexperienced employees. Give new team members a chance to prove themselves before taking work away and hanging them out to dry.

evaluation: Positive Outlook

Cons: Upper management is far removed from regular employees, and sometimes those decisions can adversely affect basic employees in unexpected ways (like group rearrangements).

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: -Great pay -Decent benefits, supposed to get better soon -Friendly office environment -Nice building amenities (gym, bike storage) -Plentiful educational material (Red Vector, Pinnacle Series, Webinars) -Project management trainings (PM Cafe) -Work from home is seamless -Very generous with making own schedule
Cons: -Have never received a bonus, or heard of others receiving -Minimal social activities within the office -Not big pushes for office engagement
Advice to Management: More fun stuff, technically and career wise it is a great company but we could use more giving back to the employees. Lunches? Breakfasts? Get fed for work from home meetings? Better share of health care paid for by the company would be great as well.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: The company has some super cool projects.
Cons: There's a lack of accountability and transparency, and the organization isn't set up to naturally value people--what a company's biggest and best asset should be. Overall, there's a lack of authenticity as people are valued only for how much work they can churn out. You will be burnt out, and have to have strong work boundaries to handle the amount of work that will come your way. They say it's just hard times--don't fall for that.
Advice to Management: Please really value people; make it so people can feel safe emotionally; don't ever have an anonymous internal survey that isn't anonymous; have management be accountable (I had an awful boss, but was completely stuck and unable to really tell you how bad this individual was); really truly encourage vacation (I left completely burnt out and emotionally tapped). Management should seek counsel from representatives of their intended audience for buy-in (there were some communications that were released prematurely that didn't promote positive culture). Have better exit interviews--spend a whole two days with exiting staff. I would've given you a slew of information to improve because I truly care about so many people who work for WSP. But no one asked. I left in kindness because that's who I am, but don't mistake that for disappointment with my time at WSP. There are some great bosses, but that's truly up to them, and not part of your framework to build good bosses. Also--I had a friend who was laid off unexpectedly. I was told she was given a "great package" and that management "really took care of her." This individual told me she was initially given a week of pay, and she had to argue for a second week. This is despicable that this was all this person received and that I was told that this person was taken care of well. I was very disappointed with management in this lie. I know you don't know the full context, but I can tell you without a doubt that this person wasn't allowed to succeed, and this was even admitted to me by management. Also--it was told to me that management learned from this, but this wasn't an isolated event. Hindsight needs to be turned into foresight, but I don't think anyone had the help they needed to do this.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: Some of your coworkers and a few of your supervisors will be good.
Cons: They will call you in the middle of the CoViD-19 pandemic to tell you that since their archaeological field techs AS A GROUP work, on average, less than 24 hrs/week that none of you now qualify for any health benefits. Leaving you without health insurance in the middle of a global pandemic because, realistically, they do not care about their low-level employees. Do not work for WSP as an archaeologist. It will never be worth it. Only one of the field techs doesn't live at home with their parents because we get payed very little for even less work and the "per diem" is never worth it.   In addition, it will not be a good situation for you to be in if you are a person of color. Most of the supervisors are good to work with, but you may work with one who is racist and enjoys using racial slurs just to prove that she can, forgetting that some of her crew are people of color.   The whole department is mismanaged with horrible communication to their techs.
Advice to Management: Get more of an idea of what is actually happening among your crew. Don't take away their health insurance in the middle of a pandemic.

evaluation: Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Lot of potential to work on large projects, intelligent people, abundance of technical resources, education assistance, some what of a flexible schedule (depending on manager). Paid overtime.
Cons: No transparencies on how to be involved in more of a project level. As junior engineer, mostly pigeon holed doing one or two tasks. If you have a field experience, will be sent to the field every chance there is. Not enough work sharing involved in the department. You will see certain people are constantly busy, and others have trouble finding billable work. Inconsistent performance reviews. Out of 4 years, only had 2 reviews, one which was in person and other was through the website. Saw a lot of brilliant people leave within the first 3 years after college graduation due to lack of communication between direct manager and junior staff, and unwillingness to provide professional growth. Overnight work is not billed at a premium rate, and expect to be in office next day. Lower pay and raises compared to the market.
Advice to Management: Try to engage your junior engineers. A meeting once every 3 months to let you know of more field work won’t cut it. Let us know how to be more involved, skills to learn to eventually take a project management role or a technical role. Have employees feel more appreciated, especially the ones that work overnight, weekends and holidays. Provide some what of a merit bonus or raise. After logging in more than hundreds of hours overtime year after year, the raises do not represent the amount of work put in.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: WSP is very generous with the amount of vacation time they start new employees with. The company also invests a tremendous amount of money into employee training and development. The company is also very community-oriented and is very active with several organizations.
Cons: The insurance is not that great and is rather expensive. Managers are inaccessible and Implement a fear-based management approach. If you are hired by this company some managers will expect you to stay there for your entire career and threatened to call prospective employers that you receive offers from and tell them that you are off limits. Managers are also not receptive to first line supervisors taking charge on projects.
Advice to Management: Trust your employees and do not micromanage them. Your employees are your best assets and they will work at their fullest potential when left alone and given the tools to do their jobs.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: WSP provides a huge range of projects for all trades within the industry. It's a great place to touch on many different things and with any large multidisciplinary, communication is easy with other groups.
Cons: Employees are given the impression their work is not appreciated. Words of praise are given expressionless and it seems the action is a chore. Delivery of project is usually expedited and quality is not always there. There's little opportunity for advancement and lots of pigeon hole situations.   Company expanded too fast and is unable to keep up with itself. The firms bought out are still functioning individually rather than the company as a whole. The expansion created a very "corporate" atmosphere and investment on employees have been severely cut. Every action limits the potential growth of new employees and younger staff.  Sub-par benefits. Typical benefits and fairly average pricing. There's a vesting period for 401K and it is only great when making under a certain dollar amount. After some years of experience you'll reach the salary and if earning more than that, company match is capped even lower.
Advice to Management: Build relationships with the new and young staff as this will help the group continue growing. Take time to show appreciation for all staff members that have contributed to something unexpected like change orders, emergencies, etc. Find time to mentor staff and provide training for projects that demand the necessary quality standards by clients.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: The company is very reactive to client demands and staffing. A small portion of the workforce carries a significant portion of production. High performing individuals tend to have a very poor work/life balance. Company does a poor job of conveying vision to employees.
Advice to Management: Identify those that are overworked and identify the causes. High performers should be identified and placed in positions that can maximize their skill sets. Be more proactive in hiring to prevent burnout.

WAY too many chiefs fighting over how to proceed... and not enough indians to get the job done so you work massive overtime *for me, by choice to try to compensate my poor pay for the jobs dumped on me* to get the job(s) done. They cater too much to the client with unrealistic goals with bare bones staff vs investing in their employees longevity.
Advice to Management: Help your current employees. I'd do anything in the world for the company and I'm literally bypassed for every position that I'm well qualified for. I give everything I have to this company, addressed my concerns to my managers, and still accept everything I am task with whole heartedly with hopes for progression. I'm rewarded with more work, no increase in pay, and less support staff to assist me when needed. In one department... there is 6 managers/director to 5 staff and they fund it by decreasing the support staff...

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The group of companies is responsible for some impressive work. Lots of talent there as well, though limited to a particular demographic. The Canadian arm of the company seems to be more progressive.
Cons: Do not work at this company if you are entrepreneurial, a woman, or a minority. If you have an inexperienced manager, make sure to communicate and document issues, and if you are unable to make headway, get out fast.
Advice to Management: Train your managers better, particularly new managers. Ease up on processes and focus more on your people. Many employees feel insecure, replaceable, and not valued as individual contributors. There are double-standards between management and operations. Management needs more accountability and fewer opportunities to scapegoat subordinates. Hire less white people and start practicing diversity. The demographic is embarrassingly caucasian and male, especially leadership. Encourage your business development department to step outside of the box and be receptive to new practices. Applying unreasonable branding guidelines, cookie cutter customer-facing material, and doing business as usual because "that is always the way we've always done things" is backward. Business development needs to focus more on substance and less on aesthetics. It is more important to respond to what the customer needs/requires, not what you want to tell them.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Salary, opportunity, experience, compensation, 401k
Cons: Management believes unless you have been in the industry for more than 10 years you should not be allowed to voice your opinion. Creative thinking is frowned upon. The culture is one of harassment and intimidation. There is no justice at any level in this company. The Albuquerque office is under new management and they are trying to push a corporate agenda that hires too many people and leaves current employees with nothing to do except attack one another for petty things. If you enjoy office politics this is your place. Anti-social culture that forces you to have awkward attempts at connecting with people who are closed minded and bitter because they have not made it to where they should be after 25 years. Many managers dont even have a degree in engineering. Insecurity rules. Try to innovate or show ambition and prepare to be slowly “pushed” out as my manager put it.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: I'm working on one of my favorites projects that I've ever been on at any company. The people in my field office are easy to work with and there is a solid sense of teamwork and camaraderie.
Cons: I've yet to meet or interact with anyone from the corporate office. Outside of generic company emails, I have no attachment to the corporate mothership at all. This makes it hard to imagine advancing very far for anyone in the field. Low ceiling.   The benefits are subpar compared to other companies I've worked for. PTO is lumped together. You start with 5 sick days and 10 vacation days regardless of what level you start at (lumped together as 15 PTO days). There are very few paid holidays. We don't even get Christmas Eve off. Health benefits are middle of the road at best. Work from home policy is unclear. Seems to be acceptable occasionally.   There are also no bonuses unless you're upper management.
Advice to Management: You need to be more aggressive with your benefits offerings and work harder to meaningfully engage employees outside of the corporate office and make them feel like they have a future with the company beyond their project.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Stable employment; great projects; a lot of good team members willing to help and teach, full benefits package; most of the time you work 8 hrs per day and sometimes work longer when needed to submit deadlines.
Cons: No company is perfect but the cons from my experience are what you would experience in most big firms. Some projects move very slowly; a huge airport project I was expected to work long term on was lost so I had to struggle everyday for a few months to try to find work with other groups and see if I can be used to help them out. It was very boring and frustrating during this period but eventually other big projects came in and I started working on them and was content. One of my group members did not have an engineering degree so it's like "what is he doing here or what am I doing here?".  In my opinion I think it is better to work for a small firm when starting your career so that you get better experience since you would be given more responsibility and work closer with experienced engineers and will have a bigger part in the project. Then after obtaining sufficient experience after a few years it can be good to work for a big firm and manage your own group.
Advice to Management: Only hire engineers to do engineering work. You work hard for an engineering degree and work hard finding an engineering position so I think it is fair to hire only qualified candidates. And I think there should be structured training for entry level engineers to supplement the experience.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The people here are really laid back and not the type to pressure you if you can get all your work done. You complete your work at your own pace. Each time is about 6 people with one or two CAD operators depending on the team. There are senior staff placed over almost every team. There's a F+K community here that feels almost like family and I guess it's up to you whether you want to join it or not. There are sports teams and holiday parties that a lot of people get really into. As far as standards of work go, everyone knows what they're doing especially the senior staff.
Cons: Some downsides are that the departments may have some miscommunication sometimes as is the case everywhere, I think. It's not easy to get to know people here and so if you're looking to mesh your personal life with your co-workers that would probably be difficult.
Advice to Management: I would advise that they do a better job of identifying those key, talented people who are good for the company and recognizing them through promotions or awards or better projects and privileges, etc. There are some who go unnoticed, I think, at every level. Likewise, those who are slacking off sometimes fly under the radar as well, but many will not say that their coworkers are not doing what they should.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Great work environment. Great opportunities to work in a variety of fields. Wide range of resources available, including very experienced team members who are always willing to teach. While I cannot speak for all management, my specific management is amazing. Us lower level employees are given enough trust to allow us to contribute significantly to the team without being micro-managed.  A major pro is getting paid for overtime, which is not common for engineering firms. Fortunately, my department is rarely lacking overtime work, so there is usually opportunity to get some extra hours (I like overtime, if you can't tell). Sometimes overtime work is REQUIRED, so you'd have to be open to a flexible schedule.
Cons: As far as the work goes, I have no complaints. However, since the merger with PB, benefits have unfortunately changed for the worse, which has led many people to leave the company. There is a sense that management at the highest levels doesn't care as much for its employees as it does for its investors.   Please note that this is absolutely NOT the case with my direct superiors to whom I report to on a daily basis. They are always looking out for us in more ways than I could ask for.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great team and manager at the office level: flexible hours, good work life balance, management that is interested in your career track. Corporate Level: Opportunities to get plugged into many different projects all over the world (Key - with some/a lot of support from your local manager).
Cons: Currently there are two areas of management (Projects and People): Both have there own interest and sometime they butt heads. A lot of forms and performance measures that are not useful to PM and are not 100% clear on purpose.  Most goals for both areas are based on statistical factors which only provide a snapshot of actual happenings and can be skewed (bad data in = bad data out). Still some unknowns about what changes may be coming down the road with the buy out.
Advice to Management: Have a holistic approach when evaluating decisions so that there is an understanding of what is going on in each office and what is needed in order to grow. Decision should not be based on the number alone, make sure conversations are happening when the data suggest there is an issue. Make the data more user friendly so that it is useful all who touch it.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Experience various of geotechnical projects.
Cons: Lots of overtime required and frequently sent to the field.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: If you have a good boss, you will have a great experience. For Technical Staff (engineers): Great job security; educational assistance and professional development is encouraged, and you can climb the corporate ladder if you're capable. Amazing access to projects, decent-great salaries depending on your negotiation skills, great PTO, great benefits.
Cons: Little to no work-life balance. Everyone here works hard and OT is expected. Rather than hire enough people for the workload, they just make current employees work more. Again, if you have a good boss, they'll recognize your efforts, but it usually just becomes the norm and they don't think extra of it. 401k match is way too low.
Advice to Management: Stop trying to acquire everyone for the sake of being the biggest competitor out there, the company is becoming too big for itself and you are too out of touch with "regular" staff. Rather than reaping the benefits of a larger, more capable company (which might be possible if you actually took the time to actually integrate everyone you acquired instead of slapping them together), it is becoming increasingly more bureaucratic and creating an environment where people resent each other and are impeded from doing their jobs. Train your managers; they don't know how to effectively manage. If they can't follow the rules, how can you expect their staff to?

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: When deployed, the people in the field are wonderful to work with. Even when working 90 hours per week, everyone is teamwork oriented. Leaders in the field remind you to take time to yourself, to have fun, when you don't have any work in your pad. Very personable and knowledgeable, always happy to guide and assist. The work is purposeful, and leaves you with the feeling of humbleness and greatness being able to help those in need.
Cons: WSP does not issue travel cards as reputable companies do. You have to use your own personal money and request reimbursements. WSP accounting refuses to accept third party receipts, which is not advised to contractors until months after the expense report has been submitted. Accounting, also, attempted to gain access to my personal accounts. Accounting looks for any excuse possible to not reimburse expenses, making up random excuses about formatting of receipts or stating that you didn't submit paperwork that you did submit, and/or stating that information is missing from your reports that is not missing. They will have you submit the same information 5 times, and expect you to be on call to talk to them 24/7, though you are not in the field and are not being paid for your time. Accounting department acts like a bill collection agency, rather than an expense report processing department. Very unprofessional behavior.
Advice to Management: Issue travel cards if you want to monitor travel accounts, and want receipts to be in only one particular format.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: It's better than minimum wage.
Cons: Terrible and ineffective leadership that plays favorites and will only promote based on personal friendships. I would never work for this employer again and I've made sure all of my professional connections know that this is not a company, it's a high school clique.

evaluation: NULL

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Great projects, motivated young staff who are willing to learn. Many opportunities for growth
Cons: Very poor work life balance resulting from gross mismanagement. Great discrepancies in pay between departments for staff with similar qualifications and experience. The above issues have resulted in more than a handful of resentful employees. Focus is far greater on the money from the project than development and growth of the employees. Money often drives the project to unexpected levels resulting in unrealistic deadlines
Advice to Management: Provide a better environment for the growth of your younger staff. Networking opportunities are great, but the hard pressed deadlines make technical development nearly impossible. Establish guidelines for compensating your employees or assigning job titles to staff. Employees with the same compensation doing the same type of work should be compensated similarly!

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Work on multiple different projects at a time, gives lots of exposure to different designs. Good mix of young, recent graduates and more experienced engineers gives the office an energetic yet knowledgeable feel; great place to start and advance a career. All project managers and senior staff very approachable and wiling to answer questions or give advice. Large growth in the Bay Area for commercial (and residential) buildings. Looking forward to more integration across market sectors (structural, transportation, environmental, etc).
Cons: Staff expansion due to large volume of work and global merger with Genivar. Still doesn't seem too corporate and bureaucratic, but could in the near future if national management doesn't keep this in mind. Lots of projects means many deadlines that often require more hours. Not much formal training other than on actual projects.
