evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Always busy, never boring. This is a fast-paced and challenging environment. The longer you stay, the more PTO hours you accumulate.
Cons: Extremely slow growth potential including salary growth. The company does not seem to value longtime employees. For example, great yearly job performance reviews only get you a 3% yearly raise if you are lucky. (Each year you gain more and more work responsibilities with a very minimal raise.) To get what you think you are worth, you will need to apply to another position and negotiate a decent salary or leave the company altogether.  The company used to offer an alternative work schedule. Unfortunately, when the firm was bought out by WSP, for some reason upper management decided to do away with it. Big mistake! That was one of the only beneficial life/work balance perks that the firm offered.
Advice to Management: If your employees have a good/great yearly review, consider going to bat for that individual to fight for more than a 3% yearly raise year after year. Bring back the alternative work schedule! It’s one of the only perks that the firm offered!

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: I have no pros to offer-left as soon as I was able.
Cons: -poor salary compared to market -extremely poor benefit package -absolutely NO employee recognition, professional development, etc -corporate red tape abounds and politics are rampant to a degree unfathomable in a professional setting -poor company culture is established from top management down!! -managers have very little respect for their employees: no showing for meetings, no meeting management, being unprepared, etc
Advice to Management: I have worked for three other large, global professional services firms, so I refuse to write the issues at PB off as a result of size/scope/etc. the operation of this company is so dysfunctional that it is almost hard to believe a company like this has been around for so long. It's almost as though they are successful in spite of themselves. It's obvious as soon as you start with the company and many, including myself, were looking for new jobs within months of joining PB. Ultimately I was lucky to have the opportunity to voluntarily and joyfully leave the company.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: I'm afraid that there are no remaining reasons to continue to work at WSP|PB and it saddens me greatly. I wish that I hadn't had to resign.
Cons: The company has grown so large, by acquisitions, that it has forgotten what Consulting Engineers do for a living. We are supposed to consult with our clients so that we may design a facility that meets their need within their budgetary constraints. The Senior management neglects the needs and desires of their young staff, Consequently the turnover in my department exceeds 100% per DOL formulae. I honestly don't know if the problems are size related (>30,000) or if it's just poor management, but either way it's no longer the pleasant place to work that Flack+Kurtz was. I do suspect that being a publicly traded company has had a large negative impact. Benefits and remuneration have suffered greatly. The best Senior and middle Managers have left for greener pastures. Their replacements just don't measure up.
Advice to Management: Start paying better attention to the foundation of the company. Take care of your staff. The senior managers need to keep a better eye on their middle managers, some of whom have only their self-interest in their minds and hearts. Restore competitive benefits. Stop waiting until staff resign to give raises. Listen to your staff without the "middle manager filter".

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The other employers were very nice and happy to talk with me and offer me advice for a career in structural engineer, which I was looking for as I was only an undergraduate student. They paid me well for an internship and, though everyone was very busy, were very kind. They tried to expose me to the field even though I didn't yet have the education to really do engineering work, which is what I was looking for.
Cons: The distinction between the higher level staff (CEOs, presidents, senior engineers) and lower level staff (regular engineers) was very prominent, with the two groups working on different floors of the building. I think that if I worked there as an engineer I would have felt very intimidated by my uppers because of this set up.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Most colleagues are good to work with, flexible hours, nice lunch rooms in most instances
Cons: Antiquated technology for a global company, not enough staff to integrate so many acquisitions, benefits are horrible, pay is half of what other companies offer in the same area for the same job, petty whining in an open office, no formal performance review, no money for learning and development, turnover in certain departments is high, people only stay until the better job comes along, no interest in retaining top notch personnel, departments work in silos, bonuses only apply to certain grade levels (not conducive to working and contributions made by a team)
Advice to Management: Slow down and get it right before you fail! When you ask for feedback and get it, act on it. Your people are your most important asset and can give you a competitive edge, so recognize it by having a total rewards package that makes sense. Get your act together and invest in technology and people to get your data and processes working efficiently with accurate information to promote success. Everyone plays a part in the company's success or failure so recognize it!

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Outside of IT, the WSP business has been extremely helpful and encouraging.  As a young professional I still have a lot to learn, there have been multiple high-ranking employees of the Baltimore, Bethlehem, and New York offices who have taken me under their wing and mentored me. I would say WSP really looks out for the younger generation internally.
Cons: IT... as whole  In my career in IT at WSP I've been "promoted" twice without an accompanying pay raise. The excuse has been "Lets revisit after a year" then after a year goes by there is some other excuse. This has also been the case for a few other IT   Another problem is IT doesn't hold anyone accountable. There have been several employees who, despite committing egregious workplace errors, continue to be employed.   At the Service Desk level, we've hired quite a few contractors which I assume is common these days. WSP is FLAT OUT LIEING to these poor kids, telling them the position is 6 month Contract to Hire which is completely untrue. The Service Desk will be completely outsourced on August 1st.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great company to work for and they try hard to help us be productive.
Cons: The paid is based on productivity so if you are lucky to have a great field supervisor who have patience and know how to train people, you will do well. If not, good luck. A lot of inspectors I know quit after the first deployments because they got so frustrated or not making much money. However, if you complaint, the company will listen and won't hire them back I think.
Advice to Management: Don't hire people to train just because they are the most productive inspectors in the past. They might be the worst trainers. It's a nightmare for an inexperience inspector on the field to learn from a field supervisor who are verbally abusive and impatient.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: -Early exposure and responsibility on large scale projects -Young office with good gender balance, a softball team, and the occasional happy hour -Plenty of PE's to get recommendations from for those looking for qualifying experience to take the PE exam -Plenty of PTO (less for new hires) -Good engineers to learn from, although more personal initiative is required to capitalize on this.
Cons: -Increasingly restrictive work environment -Production focused, little effort to involve lower level engineers on initial design decisions -Half measures to increase employee satisfaction like an employee committee and ping pong table, while stripping benefits, reducing review and raise frequency, and limiting decision making power of the local office. -Mass exodus of experienced and innovative upper management since Flack + Kurtz was acquired by WSP Group
Advice to Management: It has become a more and more stifling work environment exemplified by a lot of good talent leaving. An effort would need to be made to restore more local decision making and employee benefits, instead of creating bandaids of generically inspiring mission statements and organizing a quarterly pizza and bowling night.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Some fun employee activities, flexible schedule. Could be a good place to work as a young engineer, however, know that it's mostly "sink or swim" as many senior engineers have left and there's not a lot of mentoring happening. Colleagues are the best part of working here, or at least had been, camaraderie is on the decline.
Cons: No mentoring, folks are stretched thin. Not enough compensation for the work being done. Some people are hard workers while others are constantly online looking at FB or online shopping. No support for engineers. Feels like a free for all. Many senior management left in 2015-16 and that really was a blow to the office. The person left in charge has zero people skills and poor judgement. The company overall seems to have lack of better judgement. The HR and IT departments are laughable. How do you hire an HR person who has never worked in the United States before, let alone San Francisco?
Advice to Management: If you took the time to conduct an employee survey, then you should actually read and implement the changes that your employees suggested. Stop blaming past employees for the demise of the office and accept responsibility for your lack of management skills.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: This company has great benefits and the coworkers are excellent. The company also seems to put forth a good effort to streamline departments.
Cons: Within the company you will find no structure or oganization. This is several departments across the board. When I came aboard the HR department was not very together. My paycheck was wrong and I had a hard time getting my benefits started. When I came to work in my department - trainning was non-exsisted. Not because management did not have time- but because management had no procedures in place to follow. This seems to be the norm here at WSP NY - I figured this out becuase like I was saying with my paycheck and benefits- several calls was made and nothing was done to correct the mistake. Even after speaking with the manager (T.V) she still managed to overpay me - Oh well, I guess I can use the extra cash
Advice to Management: Get new management that has a background in the department they oversee

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Legacy firm is nice to work for. Decent folks. Very family minded. Nice work-family balance.
Cons: Grew too much, too fast. Like Cancer. We want from some corporate oversight to full on corporate policy b-s. Growth has not been organic, and some of the promises made using merging are superseded by promises they have to make to other firms that are acquired. Locally, people's career path is not respected because it is in conflict with new firm direction, i.e. your job is made redundant because it's not the company's focus anymore.  Local offices in smaller markets are used to outsource expensive work, leading to people being compartmentalized and lower wages for employees.
Advice to Management: Firm wide, maybe leadership needs to figure out how much more they want to keep growing before developing some serious issues.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: The PB brand has a ~130 year legacy and is widely respected. At its core the company still values technical excellence and a commitment to its clients that is probably second to none.
Cons: Cutting overhead is not a growth strategy. Investment in the training and development of its people, particularly its PMs and Project Accountants has been pretty much eliminated over the past 7-8 years. The firm wants to excel in the at-risk environment. Yet management believes the PMs it hires or promotes will naturally excel without deep training -- and with contractor clients no less. Similar problem with PM tools -- the Project Accounting system has seen very few improvements since 1993. The better PMs run their projects in Excel. This is not sustainable long term.
Advice to Management: Take a hard look at the erosion that's occurring in the skills of the people who manage your projects, and stop believing that an engineering license is assurance that someone has strong business and project management capabilities.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: PB is a premiere corporation offering services across the engineering spectrum. They supply superior customer service and high quality design and construction services.
Cons: PB having been recently acquired by WSP is conducting an aggressive review of staffing needs and many senior staff are feeling the pressure. Several senior staff have been furloughed as a cost cutting measure and will ultimately face layoff. Previously, prior to acquisition, PB work ed very hard to retain staff in anticipation of new work.
Advice to Management: Show loyalty to devoted staff and make every attempt to show that they are the primary asset to the company. Retention incentives should be sought for the best talent.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: The company has opportunities statewide and worldwide. It is at the forefront of engineering and construction management. One of the original owners was the inventor of the third rail. if you like travel or if you'd like to relocate, this is your company.
Cons: The benefits are not very competitive. Annual sick days and vacation days are very few. There are plenty of company programs and activities for self-improvement. but, if you are in a field office, you have limited access to these programs. A lot of field office people also feel left out out or forgotten.
Advice to Management: Take care of the field people and give annual raises.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: I like the "possibility" of helping people in their time of need following a disaster. Additionally, the opportunity to live anywhere and still participate with this company is a huge plus for my future plans.
Cons: The disaster on-boarding process was chaotic and hectic but it does seem to work. During this downtime I would like to have some "ride-along" opportunities.
Advice to Management: Rotate newbies through experienced inspectors for a couple of days prior to full deployment. Offer badged but un-deployed the opportunity to "pay their own way" for an opportunity for ride-alongs with experienced inspectors.

evaluation: Neutral Outlook
Pros: Quick to hire and a brief training for work to be done.
Cons: The 2017 disasters were too much for WSP USA management, the 3 critical areas they have failed to provides a functionable support service is: Field inspector questions for non-STD housing issues.  Assigning of more inspection cases in a timely pace.  Field inspector questions to the accounting function for Expense reports, I call their number 101 times and always get a busy signal or I get a answer service to leave a message with a question and call back number. No response from this department. It is over 3 weeks (Oct 23 2017) since filing an expense report and not 1 word from this department. How long will it be to these expense reports processed and paid. How about some form of status communication???
Advice to Management: Invest in systematic functions that the disaster field inspectors can use to get their issues clarified and resolved.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook
Pros: Paid for overtime after 42 billable hours. Work with super friendly team. Bosses were super open and understanding. Given autonomy with good guidance.
Cons: Pay below industry average. Easily pigeon-holed into certain roles. The US group seems to be a small pawn to the London group. Management was all engineers with no real business acumen and clear vision to grow the business.
Advice to Management: Need to get staff more involved in the feeling that they are helping to build the business, that they are part of something larger if you want more attrition.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: There seems to be change happening all the time, and the company is growing through acquisition. The company is doing the right things to become the biggest player in the market including making sure they focus on people.
Cons: There is some growing pains and understanding what changes are in the pipeline for the region and how much global will attempt to step in and run the regions.
Advice to Management: To get the best, you need the best. To get the best, you need to offer better benefit packages.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: -Salary (WSP is working quickly to fix this "Pro") -Alternate Work Schedule (which they're removing effective June 1.) -BYO Mobile Plan (for now)
Cons: -WSP has single-handedly ruined Parsons Brinckerhoff. They laid off 80+ salaried full-time employees. Moved positions to other offices without telling the business or anyone at Parsons Brinckerhoff. Have hired seasonal interns to do the work of said salaried full-time employees. Talk about a compliance nightmare.  -During those layoffs, affected employees had to take PTO to interview to find another job. Are you kidding me?! -Those unaffected have been bailing left and right. HR function is a shadow of its former self. -Micromanagement of individual contributors. -Constant revolving door of line level managers. -Petty corporate politics. -Cutbacks and layoffs all to save a buck. Which they will then turn around and spend on acquiring yet another company.  -Zero communication. -Small low cublicles with zero privacy. Teams expected to duke it out over small huddle romos to make calls that are sensitive in nature.    My advice to you, keep looking. This is not a good place to further your career.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The company has an excellent reputation as a top-notch engineering firm. Employees take great pride in knowing that PB was instrumental in building the original NYC subway, developing early rail lines in China, and that PB continues to be part of important and exciting projects around the world.
Cons: Shortly after being hired by this engineering leader it became clear that the company under-values any employee serving in a support role. They've already cut staff, limited increases and promotions, and removed everything that might improve employee morale in their quest to maximize profits and reward senior management and engineers. This employee questions the ethics of the company leaders who promote these policies.
Advice to Management: Re-evaluate the policies that impact your administrative and support staff. You may consider us expendable - but we are real people with families and mortgages and dreams. We deserve to be treated as the valuable contributors we are.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: The building is beautiful, they provide a modern workspace. Billing supervisors may scare you into believing the project accountants (PA) are scary but they are very understanding and nice.
Cons: No hesitation to fire someone. I was there for only 2 months and they had fired 5 people with no solid reason for the let go. The billing department is a mess. A lot of employees are on edge and scared because of this culture. Heavy biller turnover, PA's has to do the billers job.   Employee morale is low. Employees can't have a mind of there own. When you are working with others they respond to your emails by contacting your manager who communicates to you that the person can't meet for training, almost all communication goes through the manager even the smallest things. Manager and supervisors are very territorial.
Advice to Management: Managers don't be influenced by supervisors opinions but go off of facts. Favoring employees should be a no no. Professionals are needed in a company like this not high schoolers. Eliminate the fear so employees can focus on the work and that may lower the turnovers.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: A great training program and ongoing training when necessary. Keeps Inspectors up to date daily on changes per Client requirements
Cons: During disasters, can be difficult to get through to an actual person during midday. Contract Inspectors need to be prepared for out of pocket expenses during the first month. Expenses can be up to $2000 to $3000 the first month. Delays in reimbursement for out of pocket expenses can take as long as 2-3 months. Advise: Keep a detailed log of expenses on a daily basis if possible.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Intelligent, flexible, professional employees who are great to work with. The company has truly values. Lots to learn, opportunity to be involved in many different aspects and projects. Management demands quality work from everyone, so pushed to deliver exception results. Opportunity to impact the company and develop processes and procedures.
Cons: Benefits aren't great - health insurance, maternity/paternity leave. Some of the technology is dated.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great diversity in projects, especially considering across all sectors/groups. Many recent acquisitions have enabled this. This can sound overwhelming, but for the most part, everyone is busy learning about all these other sectors and service offerings, now that we're all under one name. If you have an idea , odds are your manager will let you run with it!
Cons: Some typical large/growing company challenges (like merging IT, communications, behind-the-scenes systems).
Advice to Management: Continue to be open-minded and accessible to managers, associates and staff below you.

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: The knowledge and skills of the technical staff is very high in their respective fields. It was easy to get along with almost everyone.
Cons: There were a small number of people in my area of practice, so there were fewer opportunities for advancement. For most prospective candidates, this wouldn't be an issue.
Advice to Management: Standardization can be good, but not everything which meets the needs of other divisions is good for E&E and could result in cost-shifting.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Big company, very structured, work culture is usually office specific, industry standard benefits, work sharing between offices
Cons: Politics among different departments and same department different geographic area, If you are a part of a small group then you may have to struggle for everything. Some people are treated differently based on their ability to woo upper management.
Advice to Management: Don't push departments to do better rather strive for company wide success. Managers from one department hesitate to help someone from a different department just because it may not "help" his own department.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Opportunity to work on interesting, high-profile projects throughout multiple geographies. Most employees are highly motivated and passionate about their careers.
Cons: Benefits aren't the greatest. Bonuses are rarely given, even to employees who have received stellar annual reviews. Sometimes it's hard to tell who is in charge at higher levels within the company. Multiple reorg's and acquisitions in the last five years contribute to this.
Advice to Management: Don't be afraid to go the extra mile and provide employees with spot bonuses when they do quality work, especially when working overtime for weeks and months on end.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: for new engineers it may be a bonanza of learning at multiple - many high profile - projects. The company has designed vast majority of best known hi-rises in this city and many elsewhere.
Cons: mid-level engineers seem to be stuck at that level with very little advancement and long hours.
Advice to Management: find a way to more engage and advance professionally the mid level staff.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great team to work with very professional and easy to work with. Team is very adaptable to change and embraces the opportunity to try new processes and methodologies. One of the best teams I ever had the opportunity to work with. An overall amazing experience. There is opportunity for growth and leadership is very concerned with about the teams career path.
Cons: ...a wonderful environment with no cons. The chances for growth are overwhelming. I would recommend working here to anyone who is a hard working individual with ambition

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: With a big company comes the opportunity to work on big projects. However, project type varies by office - Connecticut projects tend to be mostly program management and DSDC related with minimal design work opportunities for younger engineers.
Cons: Management asks for a lot of free time from younger employees. Biggest con is that time off is lumped together as sick time and vacation time (16 days) and cost of living increases (2-3%) never cover the increase in medical insurance. It also seems that the only way to get a raise or promotion is to threaten to leave...
Advice to Management: Reward employees for their hardwork - even a verbal "Good Job" is better than nothing. Additionally, fix issues from the "Employee Engagment Survey" instead of pawning the task off to the PGN (Professional Growth Network).

evaluation: NULL
Pros: -The hours. I rarely had to work more than 40 hours a week. -The projects. I worked on a wide variety of large-scale infrastructure projects from bridges, to railroads, to rest area development, to resilience grants, to new highways.
Cons: -Skill development. Junior staff were almost discouraged from learning anything new under the pressures of remaining billable.  -Upward Mobility. Promotions took too long and salary growth was anemic--a promotion only yielded a 5 to 7% raise, the equivalent of a public sector step up. Most other companies--not to mention the public sector--do a better job at recognizing and rewarding young talent.
Advice to Management: Redesign the promotional structure. Young talent will continue to leave in droves once they realize that salaries and responsibilities grow much faster in other organizations. Managers emerging internally will continue to have no special talents except for their ability to maintain the routine.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Good paid time off policy and some flexibility to the schedule. Fellow co-workers are friendly, hard working and will take the time to make sure the clients are happy. Solid amount of work and repeat clients.
Cons: There is little to no room to be promoted within. The company is more focused on buying other companies than trying to grow through new contracts and services. There is a focus on obtaining new employees to fill in gaps vs. promoting within. Each office is run differently. The pay is below market value, even though they stress that they want to be an "employer of choice". Year end bonuses are given to upper management while the people doing the day to day work get nothing.
Advice to Management: Focus on your current employees first. If you want to be an "employer of choice" then actually take action vs. just saying that. Cutting costs just to help the bottom line doesn't make you a better employer and doesn't help your employees. Grow the company with your current employees in mind

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Interesting projects, wonderful people, and from the commuting stand point the location can't be beat for NYC employees.
Cons: Salaries is average to industry, extremely bureaucratic with the side of the company, very expensive health insurance, limited PTO days
Advice to Management: To retain employees you need to increase PTO days and make benefits more affordable. The level of bureaucracy is insane. 10 people are doing a job that 1 person can do.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Excellent company and will be a part of history. Major projects that will withstand the test of time. Upper management most considerate of all employees. Great salaries and backing of next level management. Team work was the greatest with fellow employees.
Cons: Middle management has and uses the "Good Ole Boy Syndrome". Professional skills ignored if employee migrated from another industry, especially if different from middle management.
Advice to Management: Beware of Middle Management as this level of management will untimely destroy the company from within.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Interesting projects. Some are mega projects. Able to get big projects. Parsons Brinckerhoff brand. The people are great! Overtime opportunities but depends on the project your placed on. Great work life balance but that also depends on your manager.
Cons: Health benefits are pricey. The Construction Services Group need to get more projects for the staff!!!   They will bid on design first then construction management second if they lose on design.
Advice to Management: Please get more Construction Management contracts for your staff.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook
Pros: US Advisory Services has a great group of brilliant thought-leaders in transportation. Young professionals are able to work directly with some of the best and brightest in the field.
Cons: There is no set path for advancement for young professionals. Promotions are not performance-based. Associates are overworked, underpaid, and do not have any of the major benefits provided by other consultancies (bonuses, phone stipends, etc.). Management is too focused on cutting costs, and would rather hire someone in from the outside at much higher rates than grow high-preforming staff from within.
Advice to Management: Invest in your people and grow them into tomorrow's leaders. Think long-term. Transition to a transparent, performance-based promotion practice that rewards and retains your best employees. Admit that you have a retention problem related to poor hiring and promotion practices; stop blaming it on the millennials.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great co-workers  Opportunity to work on multiple projects and in different locations Local management supportive of staff Lot of work
Cons: Utilization is emphasized too much Cost saving measures are probably costing the company more than they are saving
Advice to Management: Find ways to positively encourage your employees at the corporate level. Within the local office management was very supportive. The corporate level is very detached from the actual work of the company.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: The company size allows you the opportunity to work on a wide range of projects. Great people and work atmosphere. Flexible hours and schedule.
Cons: Slow development of junior level staff. Benefits are not as good as they were in the past. With new Owners, would like to know what the future will bring.
Advice to Management: Begin to incorporate junior and mid-level staff into new roles and positions.

evaluation: Recommends, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Reputable name across multiple sectors, talented professionals, and high-profile projects. As a young project manager the growth opportunities are a plus. Having a global presence doesn't necessarily geographically restrict you. Overall a good work environment.
Cons: Average to low compensation, zero stakeholder equity, and behind the times employee benefits. Huge gap in median age employees.
Advice to Management: Recruiting is easy with the reputation and high profile projects that the PB name brings but retaining talent with low compensation, no stakeholder equity, and poor benefits will be difficult. Show that you appreciate your employees and the millions that they generate every year. Even small things, gym memberships, food catering, PTO, flexible work hours, etc. go a long way in passing the message along to employees that they are valued.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Was given the chance to work directly with multiple highly talented engineers on full scale project and was given the responsibility and resources to make an impact on the productivity of the team and product.
Cons: Interns are not allowed to take paid time off so there were three holidays that I was forced to take off without the PTO which was unfortunate but not a huge deal.
Advice to Management: Keep it up, I really enjoyed my time with the company.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The people are really smart, technically skilled and perhaps most importantly, inquisitive. The leadership and SF local office is definitely working to distinguish itself in a sea of engineering conglomerates by being creative and relatable.
Cons: The benefits aren't the best, maternal/paternal leave is embarrassing, employees are often underpaid and under recognized due to lack of appropriate and adequate structure for this.
Advice to Management: Value and recognize middle tier employees. Reviews and check-ins should take place at LEAST every 6 months.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Typically the office is busy and has multiple projects going on at once. Projects are normally of a larger scale and not cookie cutter. Open office environment has its benefits at times. Primary software used is now is Revit.
Cons: Employees are often left feeling disposable and unappreciated. Yearly office cuts cause worry among many employees. The longer you're here the more PTO you will accrue. Health insurance has changed and not for the better. Yearly raises are below inflation increases.
Advice to Management: Please take time to show appreciation to those willing to put in the extra effort to get projects out on time when last minute changes are made by owners & architects. Bring back flexible work hours and half day Fridays year round. Spend more time mentoring new hires and graduates.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Some of the best engineers I've ever met worked at Flack + Kurtz. I learned so much from them while I worked there. The projects are world class, and I gained vast experience from net zero campuses, to landmark high rise buildings.
Cons: Compensation just about average and one has to fight to get that. Company was very well run by management until multiple takeovers introduced a big corporate structure.
Advice to Management: Return focus on employees, satisfaction, retention and development.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: There are some truly wonderful people working here. They make for great experiences and awesome mentoring. They make it easy to get up and come to work.
Cons: Unfortunately, those higher up the hierarchy are not the most pleasant people. They also tend to forget that those of us on the bottom rungs do everyday what they don't know how to do. Also, unless you are making a lot of money, this can be a VERY expensive company for which to work.
Advice to Management: Please stop forgetting about those of us who work little clerk, analyst, and biller jobs. We may be little cogs, but your machine would be broken without us. It would be nice to not be treated as though we don't matter to the executive team.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great pay. Quickly responds to all resumes and E-Maila about employment. My immediate superiors were knowledgeable and great people. National H.R. made any issues, no matter how small unfixable because of communication difficulties.
Cons: Zero cons except for winter layoffs but they do everything in their power to not lay anyone off that they can help.
Advice to Management: Listen to employees when you have anomalies. Don't just throw out the baby with the bath water.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great managers, great employees, and my favorite, free coffee! The building was nice, the gym inside is nice and the cafeteria is nice for those days when you don't feel like packing lunch. My team worked together well and everyone was always bringing food items in to brighten up the day a bit.
Cons: None really. I did my internship as I was supposed to and finished on good terms.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The office in the past few years has undergone significant turnover, however seems to have come out stronger because of it. Always has and will have great people to be around inside and out of the office. Great opportunity to start your career as you get to work on great projects from day one.
Cons: Those that are left have to pickup and rescue the projects started by employees that have left.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Most of the employees are extremely nice and willing to help. Anytime an intern asks a question employees will always take time to answer. Not much separation between upper management and entry positions, everyone interacted and talked.
Cons: The group I was with unfortunately stuck on a major project so a lot of my work was monotonous but all the other interns had a big variety of work in office and outside of office.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Interesting projects, lots of independence in terms of work schedule and location (this applies to strategic consulting, not the engineering side of the house).
Cons: Health care is expensive, little communication about when raises are considered, bonuses are lacking, little information about what must be accomplished in order to receive a promotion.
Advice to Management: Better communication with employees and encouraging interaction among different groups of employees.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Good working environment and talented people to learn from, with a good focus on professional development. Nice office and good facilities.
Cons: The company was constantly reorganizing so it didn't always feel like there was good continuity or a clear vision. Poor hiring sometimes, but management was not afraid to fire underperformers.
Advice to Management: should have more professional development opportunities for more junior level staff, and find a good organizational structure and stick to it.

evaluation: Recommends, No opinion of CEO
Pros: A large company to experience all levels of engineering with chance for advancement throughout the US and world, other than the Boston office
Cons: Overpowering upper management in the Boston office not allowing junior employees have input or to be apart of the decision making process
Advice to Management: Overpowering upper management in the Boston office not allowing junior employees have input or to be apart of the decision making process

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Work on a diverse selection of project and building types. Have great people with charisma. Good internal resources and ability to work with other offices. Potential to work in another office in a another city. Great at letting young engineers take the lead to learn how to become self-sufficient quickly.
Cons: The company continues to expand, merge and acquire although it has never properly unified its businesses. Many corporate actions are only at the benefit of the shareholders and not the employees. Broad direction is given from above without consideration to the local markets.
Advice to Management: Get a better sense of the skills and abilities of your employees. Take the time to ask them what they would like to pursue and give them space and time to pursue ways to innovate and grow themselves and the office.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: WSP is a great company to work for. There's an awesome company culture. Everyone is willing to help out. A lot of younger designers and engineers, which is great. A really diverse range of projects.
Cons: WSP is in the process of expanding very quickly. Everyone is very busy and not sure hiring is keeping up with the amount of new incoming work.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: Technical excellence, high-profile projects and offices all over the globe. Good team-oriented approach to delivering mega-projects. Great opportunities to work on multiple projects in a short time.
Cons: Lots of culture change and emphasis on bottom line due to multiple mergers and acquisitions over last several years.
Advice to Management: Work on retaining your junior employees, the majority of people in the 0-5 year range have left in the time I have been employed there.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great work atmosphere. Everyone is very driven and caring! Free coffee and tea. The office is extremely nice being right on the inner harbor.
Cons: The office does not pay for much (parking, dinners, etc...)
Advice to Management: Good job on structure and buildings. Would recommend spending a little more on employees for little things like dinners when the office goes on a trip or does community service.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: A technologically savvy and energetic team of experienced professionals that endeavor to achieve excellence and deliver optimum benefits to their clients.
Cons: The organization is with the long tradition in the market and many successful major infrastructure and mass transit projects.
Advice to Management: Maximize efforts with professional networking, branding and building a portfolio of successful and significant project delivered to the industry.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Scheduling freedom. Realistic billable goals. Exciting and varied technical work. Highly-skilled technical staff. Decent work/life balance.
Cons: Little possibility for career advancement past a a certain level (top heavy). Decreasing benefits. Poor business development department creates little increase in market share. Terrible mentorship program. Decreasing management loyalty with each major corporate expansion. High billing rates cause poor outcomes in competitive bidding scenarios.
Advice to Management: Find a way to more equitably distribute work to more junior technical staff. Increase staff interaction with client base. Improve/increase technical training opportunities: in-house seminars are not sufficient to stay up-to-date with latest technologies. Stop chopping salaries and benefits of loyal employees at the behest of each new corporate overlord.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great place to learn technical skills, everyone at the San Francisco office were extremely helpful. There was also a fun environment, lots of young professionals, and professional growth opportunities. To summarize, I had a great experience and learned a lot.
Cons: I think the general consensus between full time engineers is that they get paid lower than average salary for the position, especially for San Francisco.

evaluation: None
Pros: Friendly engineers and staff willing to help and teach Lots of big projects with tasks for interns to learn from Free coffee and tee (Keurigs) as well as multiple fully equiped kitchens and common area Environment feels very open and free
Cons: Some tasks are very menial May be placed on a project/task that is way out of your league which requires you to constantly ask busy engineers questions Workload can be slow at times

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: Amazing co workers, very supportive team. Respectful and hard working. Provided guidance and opportunity that is incomparable to anywhere that I have ever worked. A true honor and pleasure working with these people.
Cons: Some instability within the senior staff. With my short time there, at least two principals left the office as well as a few others.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing!

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Nice people, appreciation shown, no micro management
Cons: Benefits expensive. Took away Alternate Work Schedule which was a big benefit.
Advice to Management: Even though not many people.take part in a.benefit, for the people who.have worked for the company for a few years, the option for them to be grandfathered in would have been better. I think the medical benefits could be a little less expensive.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: All the Pros left one way or another.
Cons: As the title states. Cons people out of their previous job and HR cons you though out your stent as when good engineers leave by the masses, you are made the wipping child.    Even though of the shady workings I was still motivated to work with the powerhouse thats gobbling up every niche in the market and let my work show. I was wrong.  Higher ups would: Verbally hit you below the belt. Give you so much work to where PMs think you were incappable.  Talk down on you as if you were imcomptent. Keep you out of mettings . Lastly, change work flow when you endured all the above.   You end up leaving there in a constant state of befuttlement.   Corp just sits back and enjoys it. PB i heard such good things about . What happend?
Advice to Management: They cant add more vices to management, i hope not.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Interesting Job Sites, Mostly friendly staff/employees, Good pay rate. It was a good summer working up near Chicago.
Cons: Not enough work most of the time, project sites seemed to have many problems. Employees did complain about lack of good planning and not enough pay.
Advice to Management: I do not have much advice other than to provide interns with actaully meaningful work for the company. I expected an engineering-based internship.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Parsons Brinckerhoff (PB) invested in their employees PB centralized global functions, resulting in global consistency and economies of scale savings PB provided work flexibility
Cons: After WSP purchased PB, investments in employee development ceased. WSP decentralized many functions and took a regional approach, resulting in a patchwork of systems and support staff. Each region now has to purchase their own systems, resulting in drastic increase in costs. Management only wants to push costs down to regions even if it ultimately costs 10x more money. WSP doesn't understand or care about work flexibility/employee happiness. Upper management is too busy trying to grow business through acquisitions and is not focused on managing current business. Once acquisitions take place, the integration process is poorly communicated and sloppy at best.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great projects. Great opportunities to learn and grow. Management is happy to delegate and give increasing responsibilities. Great colleagues to work with. Great work life balance.
Cons: Low and slow pay raises. Very small performance bonuses. High and potentially unfair discrepancies among employee salaries.
Advice to Management: Compensation framework needs to be fairer. Best employees leave the firm because they are not promoted when they should.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook
Pros: This company is formerly known as WSP Cantor Seinuk, or Cantor Seinuk. Firm is working on major high-rise buildings in New York. The company is located at 45th Street in New York.  You will be very likely working on challenging projects. Good company, if you want to do one thing repetitively. You are never alone at work at 7 p.m. Close to subway. Great spreadsheets - fool proofed. You do not have to come to work before 9:30 am, you can (have to) stay longer anyway.
Cons: High stress environment, big segregation (analysis - lateral members, design - gravity members, management, concrete, steel), no opportunity to become well-rounded engineer, analysis is mostly limited to input into Etabs software, design is mostly limited to column rundown, slab and footing design.   When negotiating your salary take into account that the work you will be required to finish will take much more time than 40 hours per week. End year bonuses were a big disappointment.  Four of the Senior Vice Presidents left the company in 2014. Resent promotions of people without PE license and little knowledge about design proved that there are no rules in regards to promotions. Company would hire new people into higher management positions; however they are not offering their loyal long-term employees opportunity to grow professionally. Company prefers to hire engineers with any kind of experience and gives only from time to time opportunity to graduates.   Do not show you are capable to design quickly and efficiently, you will get stuck in the Design Engineer position and your peers that cannot design will become more appreciated Project Managers. You are going to get easier promoted if you show to the upper management that you can be pushy. Amount of work completed by you does not matter, what matters is that you make other people work really hard and make them work longer hours. Crazy deadlines: you are working on your project deadline or you are helping somebody else with a deadline.   Drafting department is understaffed.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: If you work hard , the right opportunities will avail themselves to you.
Cons: The company is very deadlne driven.
Advice to Management: over the years the company has lost a little bif of its spirit in the age of being acquired or acquiring others. It needs to regain its vision even as part of a large company.

evaluation: Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: great people, autonomy in my work
Cons: too much change in too short a time period; transition to WSP not being handled well
Advice to Management: This is more about WSP - they talk "clear direction" and "global collaboration" but it's not translating in daily business. Too many silos. Too many people not talking to each other.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: PB is a great company to work for as a new grad. It has great resources to teach you everything you need to proceed forward.
Cons: Corporate is too large, so the benefits like health insurance is not so great compared with other companies.
Advice to Management: Focus on talent cultivating and benefit packages.

evaluation: None
Pros: Able to accommodate for new, young employees. Great future ahead for the company. Excellent care of the employees.
Cons: Not many cons that I can consider for this company so far in my experience.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: Salary is descent. People are great
Cons: Executive leadership refuse to staff to the needs of the group. As a result, workloads are out of control driving 70+ hour weeks. Some staff are able to claim OT even if they are exempt while others cannot. Senior management Try to get results by cussing you out in front of peers and other executives.
Advice to Management: Management needs to recognize the work being done by the staff and show a little appreciation. Being told that I "fing" do nothing is not how to motivate people and those conversations are the reason I chose to leave.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: - Regular hours (non-engineering or technical staff) - Office is good location in SOMA
Cons: - Compensation not keeping pace with cost of living or experience - Very poor office/working environment - High turnover rate with no visible effort by management to retain talent or improve environment for remaining staff - Poor office perks with very limited amenities
Advice to Management: Find a way to bring a culture of exploration and innovation back to the engineering side. Staff is worn out and isn't performing like they could be if they were motivated, compensated and appreciated. Seriously, just do something, anything, to try to make people happier. Doing nothing isn't working.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: It is a great and friendly environment. Everyone is a great at working hard and meeting deadlines. Also great amount of teamwork displayed in the company.
Cons: There are no opportunities to advance or grow. PB don't really think long term. Poor management and leadership with some of the managers.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: A bit of schedule flexibility, Interesting projects
Cons: There are two or three troublemakers on the staff that will throw anyone under the bus in a heartbeat if it means getting ahead with the director and above. As long as they are permitted to get away with their act, things unfortunately will not change. Have seen very good people get fired/let go while the worst teammates/people stick around.
Advice to Management: Start showing that you value your people. Improve benefits, offer more competitive salaries, and get a 401k plan that is actually competitive in the industry.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Training and documentation always available for review showing how to do the job and how to fulfill expectations. Easy to use payroll and expense report system.  Timely and great pay. Flexible work balance. Great staff with with friendly and helpful attitude.
Cons: Away from home a long while but this is expected.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Office recently moved to Penn Plaza. So it's a nice new office. Health benefits were quite good too. Insurance was reasonably good.  If you wanted to really learn Etabs very well the analysis group is the place to be. A lot of big projects. Great place to get good experience for 1yr or 2 yrs max. But not longer than that. They work on some really cool projects though, I have to give them that!
Cons: For as long as I worked there, the company was split into analysis (they just do etabs models and design shearwalls and linkbeams) and design (they just do columns, slabs, beams, foundations). Very few people in the office had the privilege to understand and do both. In the end, if you stay for too long you'd be stuck knowing only gravity design or only lateral design. All the drafting is also done by a separate department. So you never develop the real skills of a proper engineer. That is: being able to design the whole building and to draft it yourself. (That I guess should be the goal of a structural engineer right?)  Also analysis engineers are given very little exposure to clients etc. so they become sort of hens in the cage that lay etabs models instead of eggs. I liked to call their system - assembly line, rather than an engineering office. Also, hours are crazy! If I left at 8pm I felt lucky! I understand bankers and lawyers work even longer hours. But they are also paid 4 times as much!
Advice to Management: Get rid of your analysis-design-drafting separation. Ok, one may start of in just one department and work there for a year but eventually you have to rotate them to make them more well rounded. Otherwise the talented engineers will leave you as soon as they can.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: It's a job and they pay on time.
Cons: 1 WEEK of maternity/Parental leave...if they could they'd give you less. 1 week people, tells you how they value their employees.  WSP is too busy empire building to actually manage what they are aquiring, the staff is mere necessary inconvenience to management.
Advice to Management: Get competitive with benefits or stay on the C team as far as recruiting talent.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP is a great company for young engineers to start their careers. In here, you can pick up structural design skills quickly under excellent supervisors. Company also provide great opportunities to the employee to share their successful experience.
Cons: Depending on the project deadlines project deadlines could be very stressful.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The people are great! Overtime opportunities but depends on the project your placed on. Great work life balance but that also depends on your manager.
Cons: The Construction Services Group need to get more projects for the staff!!! They will bid on design first then construction management second if they lose on design.

evaluation: None
Pros: Solid hourly rate, very friendly people that didn't mind being asked a lot of questions. Got to work on a few pretty cool projects,.
Cons: A solid amount of repetitive busy work. I worked in their bridge group and the majority of the work was fairly cookie cutter highway bridges

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great people and working environment, good company culture. Boston office staff was great to work with, and most remote and corporate staff was very easy to interface with.
Cons: Long hours, not a log of flexibility from IT managers. Felt like a lot was micromanaged and there was a disconnect between IT managers and what was actually going on within the IT staff.
Advice to Management: New IT leadership who came in in 2013 did not take the time to understand workload and dynamics, let alone skillsets within their team to handle effective distribution at work. At times, there was not enough ground level staff to handle the volume.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Comfortable environment, kind people, meaningful work. Great location, very close to Times Square. Paid lunch hour.
Cons: None to the people or company. I felt like more of an inexperienced new employee, nothing more special than that. No group intern experiences or anything of that nature, just work.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Mike Unger the Area Manager is one of the best in the business and truly cares for his employees. Really enjoy working for him
Cons: Typical pitfalls of a large corporation--sometimes decision makers are so far removed from a situation they make that it disrupts business.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Projectized setting allow team to know one another better and build productive team relationships. Can move on to new project / work on multiple projects simultaneously to broaden one's experience.
Cons: Could have more opportunity / training for entry level positions. Not always guaranteed employment after project is completed.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: flexible work schedule and great project work and great group of people to work with. A good amount of women in leadership.
Cons: no bonuses, low 401k matching provided, though there are a good amount of women in leadership, the racial and ethnic diversity is strongly lagging behind.

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: They get a great diversity of projects to work on Many projects are sustainable and innovative and have received awards. Leaders really care about staff and are passionate about the work.
Cons: Lots of deadlines and clients can occasionally mean long hours

evaluation: Positive Outlook
Pros: Many opportunities in almost every business line within the engineering and construction world.
Cons: Can be bureaucratic at times but when the big machine gets rolling it outweighs that.
Advice to Management: Make employees feel more important and not like another piece of the puzzle.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Sustainable engineering is a major focal point of all designs at the firm Very laid back atmosphere A great place to learn, depending on supervisor, for entry level candidates
Cons: Has become almost as corporate as AECOM Responsibility to compensation ratio is skewed Little to no quality control when submitting drawings to clients Upper level management does not support lower to mid level staff Management uses intimidation to discourage discourse regarding responsibilities/ compensation Promotion metrics are designed to prohibit advancement
Advice to Management: Start compensating low to mid level staff appropriately

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Broad range of projects to work in, plenty of travel, most of the projects are non-local, which gives great experience
Cons: A big company like this is very slow to adapt and keep up with modern advancements. Lots of red tape to get through to get anywhere. Upper management is full of older people stuck in their ways, and will try to help you advance. wages are on the lower side of average, benefits are slowly getting worse and worse.
Advice to Management: adapt, listen to the staff and adapt to the times, or your best staff will leave to rivals who will offer more.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: Flexible work schedule. Friendly colleagues. Convenient location and accessible for commuters who travel via public transportation. Modern office furniture and computer equipment.
Cons: In the past, PB has had a laid back, welcoming atmosphere; however, since the acquisition by WSP so many changes have taken place that have made it a less than desirable work environment. There is little room for career advancement. You're either a senior manager or an entry-level employee.
Advice to Management: Managers need to be more consistent with conveying new company policies to employees. There is a huge gap between communication from senior upper management and employees on the lower end of the totem pole.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: I worked with some wonderful people who were dedicated to their jobs & others on the team. I left after 4.5 years’ service and most of us started within a few weeks of each other.
Cons: Low pay Insufficient increases Many are not eligible for bonuses Management not management material - interested only in kissing their manager’s behind Very little validation for mid-level employees  Expensive benefits & crappy PTO No concept of accountability except at lower levels  Situational ethics Totally uninterested in why people leave  Walked-in one day and knew I couldn’t do it anymore. 2 week’s later, I was gone.
Advice to Management: You don’t care so I won’t waste my energy

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Only the salary. It was fair for the position and area
Cons: Horrible and unorganized upper management, sometimes hostile work environment, no work/life balance with constant overtime expected, unethical practices in reimbursing FEMA inspectors for per diem costs, outdated technology and code, favoritism (old boys club), no training, new ideas discouraged, poor benefits, high turnover rate for full-time staff
Advice to Management: Treat your employees with decency, especially those at the "bottom" doing the inspector field work. Reimburse on time as promised to inspectors instead of giving upper management huge bonuses. Invest time in training new hires rather than assigning them mediocre tasks meant for temp workers. Let your employees actually rest and take a break so as to avoid hostility amongst each other. Prepare better for future natural disasters.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great people working on great projects. As an intern, everyone was more than willing to answer any questions that I had, and made me feel welcome.
Cons: The projects are so big that you can get stuck doing the same one or two things for a while.

evaluation: Positive Outlook
Pros: Big company with a lot of resources and human capital. Very thorough in managing federal contracts. They value your time and pay you for your effort.
Cons: Difficult at times to identify and locate the right person with your question or concern.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook
Pros: Employees are not micro-managed. You are treated as an adult. Professional environment

evaluation: None

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: None

Cons: Internship was not very structured with any final deliverables like a project or presentation.

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: Working for the company provides an opportunity to help people who have suffered a natural disaster.
Cons: No known opportunity for advancement

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The NYC Office is a great place for a young engineer anyway from 0 to 5 years of experience. You will work on some really great projects. Lots of diversity in projects not matched by most other firms. The ability to take on more responsibility is there as long as you show competence and reliability.  -Flex summer hours -Laid back work environment -Lots of company paid for events like beer Friday, boat cruise etc. -Lots of overtime work if you want it. -Reimbursement for licensing applications and books.  -Decent health care
Cons: -Terrible Salaries (expect to be 20% below market value) -Terrible raises (expect to get about a %2 raise ever year if you're lucky) - Like others have said if you are below an "associate" title you are meaningless. Basically just a number and the upper management will most likely never interact with you. -Complaining to management about workload and man-power on projects is useless. Its basically a "your problem figure it out attitude" Expect to work lots of OT on some projects. -Promotions are only given if you threaten to leave or the thought of you leaving is there. -Way too top heavy with managers who do 0 production work not enough production staff. -terrible matching of 401k plan (less than 1%) -No real career path. Expect to be stuck in the same position for years unless you say something (or threaten to leave the company perhaps).
Advice to Management: get rid of some of the management to hire more people that do production work. This will elevate man-power issues. Some managers do nothing all day but talk on the phone and read emails.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: Parsons Brickerhoff is a good company with national reach. You can see the immediate impact of the projects you work on.
Cons: The work can get very repetitive and the quality of your experience depends heavily on manager and work assigned

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: Was an intern so I only spent four months with the company. People are very friendly and everyone seems to want to work together in order to get deadlines published.
Cons: Wasn't working for the company for long enough to notice any cons.

evaluation: None

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend
Pros: I was hired to do one job, but they basically had no work for me, so they sent me to work at a project office that was the worst working experience of my life. They wanted me to be 100% billable, so when the project work ended, and they had no more billable work for me, they laid me off.
Cons: Treated like dirt. I only stuck it out because looking for work is so unpleasant, but being laid off is worse. Thanks for nothing.
Advice to Management: Why not just be up-front from the beginning? Laying people off for your mistake is bad business.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Very good people, with good values and globally placed. Good opportunities worldwide.
Cons: Progression within large projects limited. Employee progression not seriously looked at in an organized way. HR in Middle East very poor.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Money, if you're in the right position, advancement, if you're willing to give up on balance, corporate backing in terms of systems and support, they attract some smart people. Generally good projects to work on.
Cons: Work/life balance is talked about but nonexistent. The profit margin requirements are pretty high so it necessitates running people as hard as possible. I have worked some hard jobs in my life, but this was honestly the most soul-sucking place I have ever been.
Advice to Management: You're smart people, figure out a way to make money while allowing people to have at least some semblance of a life.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: We get paid every two weeks as expected and on time.
Cons: Cost of benefits is exorbitant. The employer to employee ration is approximately 55 to 45 (although they will BS you into thinking its 60 to 40). 401k match is a joke. Zero flexibility-working from home is frowned upon on the rare occasion it is allowed. Compassion never enters the building...9/11, Blackout, Hurricane Sandy-use your own PTO despite the fact that there was no way employees could travel to work. While the engineers who are the bread and butter of the organization can be condescending, obtuse and mean they are outdone by the senior managers in Corporate. Diversity is a joke joke joke. Age discrimination is rampant. Sexism just par for the course. The toxicity of the New York office is epic. As a hiring manager, I can not begin to express the ineptitude of the recruitment department. I have been in this organization 10+years, there has not been a decent recruitment team in place in about 5-6 years. Is finding talent to find your talent really that difficult? Technology is woefully behind the times. And instead of addressing this, they decide to outsource the broken systems antiquated systems to save labor costs. PB was its own sad little place, but since the WSP takeover PB now looks like it was Disneyland. We had no idea things could possibly get worse. WSP walked in and said hold my beer, we can show you true miserly misery. It is definitely time to end this chapter
Advice to Management: So many talented people continue to hang in there because they remember the days of glory, but you will lose all of them to your competitors because...to put it kindly you lack vision, a modicum of altruism and ego rules the day. Oh and large swaths of your managers are bullies. Who knew President Regan's trickle down theory would actual work in the case of trickle down bullying and mean girl behavior.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: While there is significant pressure put on the marketing team, they do their best to support one another - always offering a helping hand or a word of advice. The team has great ideas for improvement, if only leadership would provide the resources and backing necessary to make them a success.
Cons: AEC marketing is a great niche industry to grow your career in - just not at WSP. Promotions are non-existent and salaries are stagnant and often below market rate.   End-of-year reviews are nothing but glorified paper-pushing as you get an “attaboy” and a vague promise that maybe next year you’ll move up or get that raise you’ve worked so hard for. But don’t dare rock the boat to ask for what you deserve...you’ll be met with open hostility from leadership backed by the incompetent HR staff.   Marketers have no say in pursuit decisions and are treated with a general disrespect by leadership. The company is grossly mismanaged - by a group of middle-aged white men who “shush” women openly in meetings.   There is no work/life balance to speak of - get ready to work regular 12 hours days because engineering staff chases ALL opportunities without vetting them properly. There are limited resources and marketing staff is stretched to the breaking point.   Health insurance is a joke, especially their one week paid maternity leave. Leadership consistently spouts the motto “work hard, play hard,” but it’s YOU working and them playing.   If you are looking for a successful, supportive team environment - one that will support your career goals and respect your life outside of the office - this isn’t the place for you. WSP offers only a daily grind of disappointment and a voiceless existence.
Advice to Management: Replace misogynistic, out-of-touch leadership with a diverse team that has proven their success with past performance. Provide the necessary resources to departments other than engineering (marketing, communications, accounting, etc.) and promote the sharing of ideas and open discussions.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: close to my house, parking garage at the building, nice break room. Clean office atmosphere. Free coffee and free bagels on payday.
Cons: Poor utilization of staff, serious lack of communication and work planning. After wsp buyout it became even worse. Insurance plans are very costly. Not enough work to keep folks busy.
Advice to Management: Be honest with the staff, treat the staff like humans and not numbers.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The firm has worked on some of the most innovative and landmark infrastructure projects across the globe. Vacation benefits are quite good in the sense that you are encouraged to use as much of your vacation time as you want each year. Good work-life balance - though downtime between projects means your job can get quite boring for blocks of time. The firm is a good place to begin a career - but not ideal if you plan on staying several years.
Cons: The recent integration with WSP has led to an exodus of key leaders and talent. WSP management has noted PB's high cost base in its most recent financial report - which was reflected in low pay raises received this year by many employees across the firm. Per company policy, younger employees do not receive annual bonuses (they are only eligible for the spot bonus program - with awards minimal in amount).  The company is very silo-ed and geographies/technical centers/business groups do not collaborate as much as they should with one another.  Promotions are very hard to come by unless you play "office politics" and actively angle for one. The firm tends to hire senior leaders and managers from outside the company - making internal promotions very difficult to come by. Mid-level managers are not empowered to guide and promote their direct reports - turnover is very high at a junior level.  The company's annual performance review process is nonsensical. The performance review form does not align well with the goal-setting form that employees are required to fill out at the beginning of each year.  Health insurance costs are high compared to other firms, due to the nature of the company and the demographic characteristics of the workforce.
Advice to Management: Empower your mid-level managers and younger staff - they are the future of the company. Focus on employee retention programs - losing talent is frustrating for both project management and business development efforts. Update the annual performance review process and follow the path of other consulting firms that are ditching annual reviews in favor of more frequent manager-employee conversations which better meet evolving employee needs.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: At present there is not one pro to working at this organization. And unfortunately, the organization is so far gone and in too deep to recover anytime soon. The support groups in small pockets like some in HR, Payroll, Marketing and Travel were always helpful.
Cons: The Benefits are expensive. If you have family, intend to have a family do not work for this organization as the benefits alone will cost you a lot. For example, family coverage on a PPO plan will run you ~$750. 401k match sucks. The average increase for benefits every year is upward of 10% yet your average pay increase is 2-3%. The organization has been belied with awful leadership. Each one successively worse than the last. Honestly I don't know who is worse the previous CEO George Pierson or the current one Greg Kelly. I'm leaning toward the latter because while George was an a-hole, I think Greg is a bigger one. Senior management across the board is just awful. The organization is in full tailspin. Women if you value your sanity and career stay away from this 75% male environment. Women are treated awful and never have an opportunity to rise and the few that have were inevitably taken out over time. If you are Black, do not bother. You will never ascend not to any real and true areas of leadership.
Advice to Management: What say you of this review? Statistics are powerful and the stats about everything I stated are factual and can be proven. So the ball is in your court, what are you going to do to make sure this review doesn't taken on a life of its own with full information spread via social media? Not one leader among you are redeemable. Do you honestly believe it is fair that the multi-millionaire making CEO pay the same cost of benefits as a receptionist? Really? Further as a manager in this organization, who went from having excellent recruiters in L.A and Chicago in our old model to having the travesty that is recruitment in Ephrata is just pathetic. Shareholders, if you want to see your stock rise, oust every single senior leader at WSP Parsons Brinckerhoff USA. Every single one and start over.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO

Cons: Leadership has no clue about the staff. How the team is trying to complete projects, lack of training opportunities for the staff. Creating an environment of distrust
Advice to Management: Come down off your laurels and see what the engineers and staff are producing. Mentor the people in the office and give them a chance to succeed

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: Heritage of firm has been destroyed by new Canadian/UK owners who have no appreciation for the proud history of the Parson Brinckerhoff Name. No one knows what WSP stands for and new logo just unveiled is \\sp.
Advice to Management: Management has alienated most PB staff, turn our business into a commodity and manages the firm from a spreadsheet.
