evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Large corporation with diverse services portfolio. Good brand name in the transportation sector. When they are in a hiring mode, there are usually many job openings for new grads.
Cons: Little re-investment into employee training, management training, tools, etc. Lack of creative vision in their approach to the markets. Stone-age management systems and laughable processes and procedures.
Advice to Management: Get serious about growing junior staff.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Work-life balance is OK; some good professionals (though many have left); 401k match vests immediately (but is subpar).
Cons: Office culture is stiff and unfriendly: staff join and leave the office without announcement. Leaders stay in their boardroom citadel; staff are kept in the dark---even as layoffs occur. A lack of communication from leadership has created an overactive rumor culture. Project pursuits appear to be approved on leadership's whim as opposed to the business case, and loyalty to leadership seems to be rewarded more than technical excellence or productivity.   Many managers are not open to new ideas and are not up to date on changes in the field. Training is very loose and some new employees get no training at all, and staff are often squeezed by pressure not to charge to projects and not to charge to overhead.   The company has only two tiers: mid-level professionals (5-20 years) are few and far between. The company does not put its money where its mouth is where career development is concerned. Promotions and raises are not tied to performance (they are decided before annual reviews are even in).  Health insurance is expensive and limited to two plans. 401k match is meager and has not increased in many years. Junior staff (<5-8 years) don't get bonuses.   The company's "furlough" practice is shady; morale is rock-bottom, turnover is increasing, and management does not seem to care.
Advice to Management: Wake up and realize that your billable staff generate revenue and are the product you are selling, so start treating them as something other than a cost and burden. If change is truly needed, shake up the many layers of old entrenched management instead of laying off or (worse yet) "furloughing" the people who actually do the work.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good pay. Equipment provided. Some training. Reimbursement of many expenses.
Cons: Extremely slow reimbursement. No warning before deployment, but worse, a sudden call tells you to leave the field and go home, the job is done.
Advice to Management: Accounting never calls or writes back. Production never calls or writes back. They reach you when they want, but are otherwise unreachable. That is unacceptable.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: You Get A Check. You have an email address. You have a computer. You can leave the office. Hopefully you know people outside of the office.
Cons: You are not valued but will be overworked. The paid isnt competitive. There are a lot of office politics. This place will take a piece of your soul. I've never felt better until I left. I strongly recommend that you find a position that will be more rewarding.
Advice to Management: Take care of your employees before another firm does.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: - A successful, recognizable Canadian company. - Provides a wide range of opportunities including foreign office exchange, and working with various disciplines and professions. - No expense spared on tech tools for getting the job done. - Good autonomy, but also a good team atmosphere at individual offices. - Company seems to have a genuine desire to be a good corporate citizen in its community, and treat its employees well. - Takes health and safety seriously.
Cons: - Health benefits leave a little too be desired. - Pay scales may not be competitive in select sectors. - New agile offices may be a challenge for those who enjoy the interaction of working in the office, but at least remote working infrastructure is solid.
Advice to Management: Need to work on the health benefits packages. Demand more from the insurance companies. Especially as it relates to paramedical coverage.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook
Pros: Before acquiring other companies and moved to mailbox office, culture was different and better. Managers were more friendly and they were representing company’s culture at the best. Office facilities are the best in Birmingham.
Cons: Management represents the old boys club. The managers know how to manipulate their employees so they become their slaves and they don't care about their mental health. You will never listen a well-done for doing something, they always want more for you if you get the job done on time. They promote those who are loyal soldiers and they change the promotion criteria every month. No transparent procedures in place and if you challenge them they will put their manipulation hat on and convince you. I believe if you want a good company to work for and feel respectful you should avoid this company.
Advice to Management: Look after your stuff as it is your biggest asset. Stop putting pressure on them and appreciate that each one has their own life and they can't work for you 12 hours per day for peanuts.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: There are no pros anymore. I have had 9 bosses in 5 years, and none of them ever know what I do. Don't believe any of what they write about inclusivity, and developing staff.
Cons: The independence that we once had has been eroded by 'operational efficiencies'. We are micromanaged to death, and expected to continue to do more and more and more with less resources. Our team has slowly been losing people with no retention strategy, and no acknowledgement of the additional stress this puts on individuals.  I can't think of a more faceless monster of a corporation. If you are early in your career avoid this place at all costs.
Advice to Management: LISTEN to your staff. When we complete an employee satisfaction survey and its all negative, don't turn around and fire half the staff on our team and tell us we are now "lean" enough to compete. Engage your staff. Try to understand what each of them brings to the table. UNLEASH the power of your people. Quit the micromanagement .

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: *Big disclaimer : WSP is a huge company with many directors and business lines. This applies to my experience only. However, I have seen/heard many similar complaints from other employees in other business lines. And overall senior management sentiment seems shared. Great collegues, interesting projects, relatively large autonomy. Great learning opportunity (even though you will need to learn on your own).
Cons: No real opportunities for career advancement. They milk project managers, i.e. compensation is at/below industry and many of the larger projects come with a level of stress you wouldn't have at a smaller firm. Not enough ressources. For such a large firm, it's quite troubling that they are unable to tap into the expertise of their worldwide people.  PMs are forced to work sometimes very long hours, for not much reward. For younger engineers : no real mentorship or structured learning. You will have to do a lot of learning on your own.  Ethics. When one of the sitting board members has been fined for ethics violations, don't preach to your employees about keeping their moral compass straight. We need no lessons from those who have profited from such ethic violations.
Advice to Management: People and culture is one of your 4 pillars. A house/building cannot stand straight if one of the pillars is weak and barely holding up. Invest in your people (especially the good ones). And by invest I mean offer more than nice words and incremental changes to benefit packages. Make compensation transparent, and give employees real objectives which, when completed, results in concrete increases in salary.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook

evaluation: NULL
Pros: The office was very nice and most of the people I worked with were friendly. I was lucky that I worked in a young team who were very social and I made a lot of good friends. Good work life balance.  There are lots of employees who commit time to organising charity events, networking opportunities and social activities.
Cons: For a fresh graduate I found I had very little opportunities to take on responsibility. Being as the company is so large, all graduates are placed on the same slow path of progression. As a motivated graduate there isn't much opportunity to excel or stand out or be rewarded for working hard.  Due to the large scale projects that the company takes on, graduates are limited on what they can contribute and so I found myself being micro-managed for a lot of my time at WSP. Although it was reassuring at first to always have someone looking over my shoulder, I soon wished I could work on smaller projects where I could take on more responsibility.  Despite a relatively high starting salary, wages rise very slowly. I started on £26k and over two years later I was on £27.5k. This was in part due to my team having two pay rises deferred during my time there.
Advice to Management: I think the career aspirations of graduates need to be addressed more. Personal development reviews would be conducted about once a year but items relating to work experience would not be actioned. I did not feel in control of the direction of my career whilst at WSP.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Very professional company, well run with excellent management. My coworkers were great to work with and were positive and highly motivated. Would definitely work here again.
Cons: Work was simplistic due to projects in challenging economy.
Advice to Management: Excellent job at keeping employees informed.

evaluation: Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: I worked within a fabulous and supportive team. My peers in other disciplines were also as great to work with. A great bunch of people to work with.
Cons: At corporate level, the need to make a profit and maximise efficiencies at the lowest cost possible unwittingly detracted from showing appreciation for their teams. Although all the health, wellbeing and strict safety measures were in place and closely followed, at times it felt like a tick box exercise rather than to put the safety of their staff first first.
Advice to Management: Appreciate the value of your staff by allowing them to meet up face to face annually to review progress over the year and build the team strategy for the next year together. Skype and Microsoft Teams certainly do have their place for productive meetings, but an annual face to face strategy meeting gives the teams a chance to relax together socially in the evenings. Some of my team members I didn't meet the whole time I was at WSP.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Hours suited me Interesting projects to assist  Friendly office
Cons: Lack of clarity with on boarding process.  Interviewed then told after that the position had been removed. Only to be contacted 2 weeks later to be offered original role.  The work I was told to assist with didn’t seem to exist. I was pushing everyday for work to be sent my way.  Put on the ‘job retention scheme’ only to be made redundant. I was re-interviewed during the redundancy pooling process, only to be told the job I was interviewing for didn’t exist. While company were making several redundancies in this country they were rehiring for the same roles in countries where employees could be paid less.
Advice to Management: Improve your communication. All decision making processes were confused and contradictory.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Your career is what you make it. If you put in the work, you can get really far and WSP will provide the resources and opportunities for you to take your career far! The benefits are great, the pay is great, there is a lot of flexibility, and I personally love the team I work with.
Cons: Fast-paced environment. Work can be stressful when your clients are demanding quick deadlines.
Advice to Management: My advice would be to try and spend time with the quiet employees too, not just the same people you're used to talking to each day. That gives us a chance to show our talent and work ethic.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: WSP has a few ongoing big job that was started few years ago which has been taken over many times by newly employers and if you like the challenges while working under pressure and dealing with the internal politics than WSP is the place for you.
Cons: Everyday you are being pressure and intimidated to complete your task by working very late including weekend, despite your superior knows that you are already overloaded and having a family to take care. Effort and hard work is very seldom or never recognize by your superior however if things goes wrong or delayed you will only be blamed. Management in WSP is like those typical type of management who refuse to acknowledge their employees feedback and constantly giving excuses just to side with the higher up to keep them happy. For the salary increment or bonus every year is low despite how much effort you put in your work due to the fact that most money are wasted on redundant things such as outsourcing BIM work which needs to redo again internally due to its poor quality, paying for certain programs license that was not being use as well mass hiring professional to do certain task which was not necessary.
Advice to Management: The turnover rate is already very high and most good employers are already leaving WSP for good, please have some common sense and solve the internal issues and employ the right person with right skills for certain management position.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: Not many good Pros: the company I worked for (Opus) was taken over by WSP.
Cons: Too much emphasis on line management, Opus had a flatter structure and staff felt valued and engaged with management. Line management is very inexperienced and top heavy (too many cost-inefficient layers) with too many approvals required from this structure to progress ANY work. Management do not make any decisions themselves or provide feedback from staff back up the chain. Staff members are made to feel small and undervalued. No emphasis on technical staff achievements and all emphasis and congratulatory speeches are made about people in management or having achieved management status. Not a very friendly atmosphere, all emphasis is on staff utilization with little provision for up-skilling or training. Recently this company has been experiencing high staff turnover as staff recognizing limited scope for career progression and very poor industry pay parity have moved on
Advice to Management: WSP New Zealand needs to streamline its management systems and eliminate frankly useless, under trained and pointless middle management that only serves to delay projects, increase stress and frustration of technical staff while driving overhead costs through the roof. Management also needs to recognize and value the personal attributes of staff something that has been completely absent from the start of the takeover 2 years ago.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Nice bunch of people doing the technical work (though many are unhappy and will no doubt start leaving). Used to be a great culture.
Cons: WSP bought the company I worked for (Opus) and it has been a downhill slide since then. It started with little changes (all pot plants removed nationwide, no more free newspaper for staff to read at lunchtime) that then progressed to changing the company management structure (going from a relatively flat structure to bringing in numerous management levels) and now they're making numerous policy changes that make doing our job more difficult and make employees feel like numbers, not people. The new management structure introduced several levels of middle management that are all ineffective and powerless. Technical staff are treated with little respect and policy changes have left us totally disempowered. Graduates are offered good training opportunities but staff above graduate level are offered nothing. The upper management is full of sycophants who constantly "slap each other on the back" for what a great job they're doing but don't acknowledge the contribution of technical staff. Numerous staff within the company were forced to take pay cuts due to Covid-19 and the upper management were very keen to inform us of the (tiny) pay cuts they also took, but they've not been very upfront about the significant bonuses many have since been paid. WSP is very quick to jump on the bandwagon when it comes to the latest trendy cause (mental health awareness, lgbt issues, diversity awareness etc) but they only pay lip service to it - they'll happily "manage out" staff with mental health issues if they're seen as a financial liability to the company. I felt very loyal to Opus as it was a great place to work - I feel no loyalty to WSP whatsoever.
Advice to Management: Get rid of the numerous middle managers.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Provides a formative step on the ladder. I did meet some wonderful people outside of my team.
Cons: Little in the way of formal training. Cliquey teams. Selection of staff based on relationship rather than aptitude. Toxic environment where bullying is seen as management and motivation. Empty promises of pay rises/ progression dangled in front of you. No value is placed on you as a person, you are just a unit of production. Expectation to work in excess of contractual hours, with no compensation or recognition. Poor disciplinary procedure which is unbalanced and unresponsive. Poorly qualified leadership. Ethics and standards guidelines consistently breached (accepting gifts, travel etc).
Advice to Management: Start from the top down and clear out the complacency, and start to focus on the people who actually do the work. Couldn't really care less what they did now, I wouldn't return under any circumstances.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook
Pros: Lots of free lunches and social clubs.
Cons: If most of your hours are non billable work, you will be a candidate for a layoff. If it is not your fault, bug your manager for work and put that as a remarks in your time sheet. Many are friendly colleagues but do not trust the upper management/executives. They are trained to fire people without hesitation if the numbers in the spreadsheet reports are not good enough. Nothing personal, its just a work for them. The way they fire people is a very surprised one, usually in the middle of the day (Friday mostly) while you are still working in your workstation without any idea, and then suddenly being approached by HR person asking you to just get your car keys, and she/he will told you that your employment is now terminated immediately without any explanation. You will then be escorted out of the office, ask you to surrender your keyfob and other company properties. She/He will say that your final payments and other benefits will be sent to your account and all your other personal stuff will be delivered to your home. And, that my friend will be your very last sad day in WSP office. .....
Advice to Management: Re-evaluate buying other consulting companies if it is worth it or not. Oftentimes, you just bought the real estate but not the people. If you don't care for the people, you end up only buying the can without the content.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Helpful colleagues, learn a lot, interesting range of projects, supportive atmosphere.
Cons: Project spending is closely controlled (which is important) yet UK wide business spends extravagantly on office refurbs and other non - project spending, which seems incongruous. Also, the need to win a lot of work sometimes results in winning work with very tight margins.
Advice to Management: Would appreciate a more joined up approach to cost management, e.g. The business spends a lot on office refits in buildings we don't own, and admin staff seem to be under much less pressure than project staff. A lot of pressure seems to be on regional discipline management for both project and operations oversight and direction.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good nailing down of fundamentals for fresh grads. Young engineers are guided for extended period before being thrown to the deep end to be independent. Good culture of encouraging discussions and asking colleagues questions to improve.
Cons: Boss shows a lot of favouritism (often not objective). Staff favoured by the boss will receive endless good opportunities and given promotions extremely quickly. Staff not favoured, even if technically strong, will not be considered for promotion or opportunities to improve. There is also a glorification of overtime. In WSP commercial dept, quantity of work, not quality of work, is key.
Advice to Management: Seek to receive genuine feedback from staff. Value staff that deliver and even have work-life balance. Promote good quality of work. Invest in improving company culture.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Poor career progression, the only way to get a promotion seems to be to leave the company.  Awful terrible woeful IT, has to be seen to be believed.   Bloated HR that seems to be at the cost of numbers of actual engineers and project support.  Very high staff turnover, hard to have work friends when they keep leaving for more money.  No bonuses.
Advice to Management: No advice really, I think they are aware of the problems but ultimately it suits their aims which is fair enough.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: They paid me at the end of the month. However, I’m shocked they got that right.
Cons: I started as a graduate here and worked my way to assitant engineer. I’d avoid this company at all costs if you want to learn the industry and progress. I was in the Highways team at First Street where they bully you to do unpaid overtime as its deemed you are “showing commitment”. They also offer very little to no support by way of teaching you or training. Their HR department is a joke and their management is completely backwards in every way . I’m thankfully with a company that treats me like an adult now. My advice would be to avoid this company and their highways department.
Advice to Management: Needs a complete re-structure the Highways department is clueless.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great group of people, easy to get along with and very helpful when you are having trouble understanding things. WSP helped build my confidence in networking and provides workshops to improve your soft skills also. WSP is a peoples company and will always fix any issues you bring up and help you transition to any department you would like to try as an intern and full-time employee.
Cons: when working under a team manager who is extremely, it is hard to get into contact and understand where you should be and what you should be doing. this can be fixed by bringing it up to the knowledge and development sector as they will help guide you to where you want to be career wise.
Advice to Management: keep in contact with your interns, cadets, and graduate to ensure they are developing as much as possible for their future career.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: On top of the competitive pay that WSP offers, it has managed to establish a balance between corporate , social, environmental, physical, intellectual and emotional responsibilities so balanced to the point that you would not even believe it is real. At WSP, it has this amazing work culture that can provide for your well being, your family's well being, has an eye for the environmental responsibilities that it holds so dear and believe that work is not just the centre of your life. It believes that employees have responsibilities outside of work. It understands that in order to have successful employees, you need to support them not just financial (but as mentioned earlier, pay is quite competitive), it also supports it's employees with a level of empathy I never even thought possible with other companies. This company has made me feel so proud to be working for it. It gives opportunities to people and gives guidance and chances that you never even thought possible. This company is not just about the earnings. it is also about who you are as a person and what's shocking about all this? is the fact that It actually pushes through with it's promise. that you have their best interest at the heart of everything that they do. What if we can have work-life balance? What if we can be rewarded in ways that support our individual needs? What if we can be accepted for who we are? Here at WSP – we can! "WSP recognizes that work is only one part of our lives and making time for the other things in our life is important – be that our families, our friends or ourselves. So, if working from home, working part-time or having flexible start and finish time will help with this let us know as part of your application." This right here is an excerpt on a job posting from WSP. and you can see just what kind of a company you are gonna be working for. the people here have been working here for mostly more than 10 years because employees are loyal and loves their work. But more importantly, WSP is loyal to it's people. And honestly, that is what makes WSP the best place to work in. :)
Cons: I wish a lot more people can work for WSP, and that a lot more clients will work with our company jsut so many more people can experience how great this company is.
Advice to Management: Keep up the great work. Keep that empathy you feel for your employees. we will always be loyal to you, as you are to us.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Easy life Little effort required to earn your monthly income Easy jobs when you get work Simple 9-5 Relaxed environment Friendly colleagues
Cons: Low pay Rigid benefit structure that does not support complimentary skillsets beyond engineering - even though they will want to utilise those while you work. Lack of work therefore you will be scrounging for it. Extremely demoralising atmosphere. Stifling growth. Local management unaware of career development and finding appropriate work for staff No engagement with any level beyond your local director. All ideas for improvements shot down or ignored. Short-sighted management; futureready is only future when it's not happening now, sorry but the branding is more appropriate as "notpresentlyready".
Advice to Management: Engage with your staff and cut out the high levels of bureaucracy. The work/life "balance" is non-existent because there was never a balance, plenty of office had hardly any work.

evaluation: None
Pros: Everyone in the company is very professional and willing to help.  I met many hard working, like-minded people.  WSP are good at Health and Safety training.  The team are not micro managed or pressured excessively.  The work was interesting on occasions.
Cons: The team rely too heavily on young members of staff in Junior and Middle management roles, this is good for some things but not others.  Low-ranking team members are viewed as easily replaceable - use of contracts is common. Favouritism is seen among a few people.  The team rely too much on Skype meetings instead of face to face meetings. Flexible working is not encouraged for anyone below senior management in Land Services.
Advice to Management: Spend a bit more time and money helping the teams to bond together.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Fantastic opportunities for self development / professional training. Nice offices. Good social events / team building.
Cons: Low salaries. Poor time management by virtually every project manager - they would sit on a project for weeks and then realize that there is only one week until deadline, so their subordinates have to work extremely long hours. Stressful environment overall.
Advice to Management: Plan your work properly. Don't take on more projects than you can complete. Employ more people!

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO

Advice to Management: COMMUNICATE!!! Talk to the people that actually do the job before placing in ridiculous policies and procedures. Hire from within and stop bringing in so much outside help that has no clue how to do the actual position that they are managing!! Yes, change is good and we definitely need better practices but they need to be implemented in a well thought out manner. Not like a bull in a China shop.

evaluation: Approves of CEO
Pros: - Awesome IT Infrastructure. You get 3 big monitors and a Laptop. - You can work from anywhere. They have flexible working hours. - Great exposure and you will get the opportunity to work on the most Iconic Projects in the Region. They don't small jobs and cheap jobs. - Good working culture.
Cons: - Racism is open and no one cares. You have to be British or white or brown noser to be promoted. Hard work and achievement doesn't matter. - They operate on hire and fire policy. They don't wait for projects to come. If they don't have projects tomorrow or next week, most likely you will be thrown out immediately. It dint happen to me, but I have seen many people losing their jobs.
Advice to Management: - Please promote people based on their achievement and hard work.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Had a continual stream of projects to work on.
Cons: During my time at WSP Canada Inc. I had no mentorship, was unfortunately a victim of constant harassment and was given no opportunity for career growth, in fact, salary (hourly wages) cuts occured every year. Not only were wages cut but starting salary had been below industry standards. Sexist jokes and remarks about my career advancement were constant. The inability to give credit where credit is due was astonishing, I was even told to take credit for developing an application which was not my own - I refused. Dispite constant thinning of employees that went on around me, the constant wage cuts and low moral - I only stayed because I needed the job.
Advice to Management: Grow a culture of respect, promote growth of your employees, and remove toxic individuals.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend
Pros: Depending on group, decent work life balance. Good variety of projects. Large company with depth of experience with multiple offices.
Cons: Only valued if you are proven to make company money. While this is common in consulting, it is a bad management attitude when applied to safety training or job progression training. You have to justify how the training will benefit the company. Poor safety culture, most of the safety policies are lip service designed to protect the company from damages not the individual. Upper management in company has some unqualified people, and it shows in the culture. Generally mediocre pay.
Advice to Management: Demonstrate that employees are valued, reward for hard work, pay appropriately (wage increases below inflation are a complete joke). Improve safety culture and focus on professional development for employees, more will stick around that way. Evaluate top management and ensure they are trained to actually manage people.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Some of PM team had a bright future. Certainly not under the current management framework.
Cons: I do not gripe about companies when they have their internal flaws, we all know that everyone has them. I do, however, feel very compelled to speak about WSP and their management in Calgary.   I was recruited by their team in pursuit of two major projects in Calgary, only to be laid-off 3 months later. This was most unprofessional after upper management had notified me that my job was not in jeopardy after not being successful on either project. 2 weeks thereafter, I was walked out due to a “business decision”. The Director unapologetically sent me the news without a goodbye, just simply a “pack your things” and go speak to the HR Rep.  Upper management ruled with an iron fist and were not willing to accept any feedback from others during proposal preparation, their own personal and cheesy tactics, nor influence in pursuit of projects. This is not the typical environment of working together as a team that we’ve all become accustomed to in being successful together.   Further, there were points when threats were made by management (second hand news but on more than one occasion), particularly to females. The bias towards males was very evident and unconscionable. It made for a very uncomfortable and ‘thick’ environment when management would exit their offices and spew their non-sensical dissatisfaction to their employees of not securing work.   Anyways, I could go on but I digress. This paints a pretty clear and honest picture of the environment within the Calgary PM office.
Advice to Management: Perhaps a review of your systemic issues with not being able to secure work is due to management of the team. The ongoing anger and bias made for a clear division of the team and did not bode well with most. With the remainder, it is my belief that they were simply too afraid to say anything given they knew if they’d had, their time with the group and company was going to be jeopardized.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: - Approachable leadership - Innovative - Open to new ideas - Willingness to try new things/change tactics - Still feels like a family company - World-class work - Flexibility - Competitive pay - Nice office facilities - Multiple locations - Free tea/coffee
Cons: As with any company that's gone through many acquisitions, there are still growing pains. If people are patient and focus on the big picture, they will reap the rewards. The company has gone through tremendous growth and change in such a short period of time. Could do with having more employee-led initiatives around culture enhancements and local activities. Could use a brand audit to remove old branded items and focus on the consistency under the new brand.
Advice to Management: Embrace the ideas that your employees have and empower them to take actions. Even little changes can add up to a big difference. Be flexible in how you allow your staff to work and where they work - focus on their output, not their timesheets.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: Below average salaries and annual salary increases which are not performance based(rediculus) and are less than inflation rates. Employees are loosing money every year, wages are not keeping up with inflation. Limited career progression. Minimal benefits compared with rival companies. Office politics and local mindset. No focus on staff retention or happiness. No transparency.
Advice to Management: Re-focus on employees particularly mid level staff. Stop rewarding high-level management with promotions while advising junior staff that promotion and salary increases were not provided due to lack of money or due to ‘poor’ company performance despite having profit margins in excess of rival companies.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: I got all the hours I could ever want. On top of a good hourly wage, that made a lot of mone. Plus there is a good benefits package inculing health insurance, RRSP contributions, Share purchase program, etc. I also had a company phone and used a company vehicle (even for personal use), so I was able to save there as well.
Cons: It was very stressful. The management made me feel stupid all the time. They say they ask for input, but never acknowledge it. I was always pressured to work more than 8 hours in a day and work on weekends as well.
Advice to Management: Go back to the MMM style. Smaller office culture, more sense of a team within the office. Pay for company events again.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: From starting as a graduate the company has supported me in my personal development through to associate director level. They have constantly offered me new challenges and areas to grow, supporting me technically and managerially via internal and external courses and personally by backing city / office relocation. I have been trusted to make the right decisions in my career and assisted to grow and develop a specialist discipline. The project experience I have accrued I'm sure is second to none. I would highly recommend a career in WSP to anyone with the right attitude and work ethic.
Cons: The biggest challenge in a big company is communication, I've seen a number of strategies but I think we're getting there. A big company can also mean that decisions that affect your career are taken remotely from your direct line management, this can sometimes be difficult to reconcile as rewards must be distributed fairly in large teams, especially in hard economic times. I've seen this lead to motivation issues with certain roles / types of people.
Advice to Management: Although I understand the difficulties in managing large teams and budgets I believe it is important that individual career paths are honoured to ensure motivation and key skill retention. The PDR process is commonly not taken seriously as it bares no real relationship to true effective progression. A culture of autonomy and personal responsibility must be fostered, the company must strive to be remain personal as it grows so all voices can be heard and all ideas assessed.

evaluation: Recommends, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great people to work with, friendly, lots of challenging work. They recognize and value good workmanship and will promote people within their own division. WSP has a great RRSP and Stock option plans. The health and benefits package is very complicated but it is close to being one of the top in the industry.
Cons: Company as a whole works in silos and does not work well within the other divisions. The company is working on this but has long way to go. Some Managers and bean counters are stuck on the bottom line, profit lines, and personal bonuses not on the people and creating a culture of helping and keeping their main resource their employees. Which d
Advice to Management: More networking between division is required, if your bidding on a job in SK and your from Ont. Then you need to communicate and get the local people involved as your work will reflect on them as well as transfer some skills to the local branch might bring in more work for you. Transferring people and skills between divisions should be a high priority. It is easier to transfer a person from Mechanical in Commercial to Industrial or visa versa than it is to hire a new person. This goes for people like project managers in BC who could be doing work in Manitoba or transferring to that community when the work moves.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook

evaluation: Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Great social life Opportunities for progression if pleasing the right people Structure is still a work in progress, leaving room for the politics savvy to grab roles with big titles and proportionately big salaries Relative diversity Most staff don't usually work overtime A bunch of people work really hard to get the business going. Although outnumbered by those who are just good are pleasing egos and not that great on their jobs, it makes the difference if falling onto the right team. Many people have been stuck in the same role for years, loosing motivation along the way. Poor opportunities for graduates, a company to land while something better comes up.
Cons: Salaries and bonuses assigned depending on upper management personal preferences, arbitrary. A one man company. Politics, politics, politics Focus on revenue generation, whilst quality, ethics or client satisfaction are secondary once the money is cashed in. Management gets the bulk of the money, opportunities for progression and credit. If you are not good with politics or pleasing certain egos, your performance will be ignored and your development will stop.  Many big job titles, loads of money leaking through company cars, company phones, (very) expensive trips and overseas meetings, bonuses. The company policy is to fire staff when money is lacking rather than cutting down on management luxurious lifestyle. Organisation is lousy, many gaps in the structure, poor procedures, when you want something done you can only get it by relying on the same small group of people, others just get away without doing things properly, very poor attention to detail.
Advice to Management: Less politics, stop listening to cheap praise. Invest on staff development, cut expenses, establish a clear, fair route for progression or resentment and lack of motivation will follow, leaving you with people who do just the bare minimum to get going.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend

Cons: -Poor work-life balance, expected to work long hours without any overtime pay. -Poor team atmosphere with an apparent lack of leadership.  - The culture of listening to who shouts the loudest. - No line management with the management often not visible for support.  - Un-transparent in management decision making.

evaluation: Positive Outlook
Pros: Lot's of really good people on a professional and personal level, variety of projects, decent salary starting off. Very big consultancy so opportunities to move about if that's what you want. Office is in a fantastic location and it is generally a nice working environment. Work/Life balance is generally good but extra hours should be expected when deadlines are tight.
Cons: Poor opportunities for training and personal development in my opinion. The company promotes flexible working but seem to question working from home or flexi-hours, maybe this changes on a team by team basis rather than being down to the company itself though. Although that isn't a reflection on work/life balance but staff shouldn't be made to feel somewhat guilty for starting or leaving at a certain time if the work gets done. Mediocre pension and benefits especially in comparison to competitors. The company has grown exponentially in the last 3 or 4 years so maybe when it settles down then the benefits and pension will improve.
Advice to Management: Either trust your staff with real flexible working or scrap it. Consider the benefits to the company as a whole over the long term by allowing staff to book time for training and development rather than a singular focus on short term benefits, ergo maximising profits.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Flexibility and work life balance are a key for my happiness and WSP has provided that in spades since I started. Clear lines of communication between upper management and the workforce. Ability to advance career unlike several of the other large Canadian "environment" companies. You are provided enough autonomy to make mistakes but enough technical support to ensure that clients don't suffer the consequences and you learn from them. WSP offers a competitive salary and a great working atmosphere. Integrity is an important component of my preferred work space and WSP has delivered in this regard. The personnel in the Saskatoon office are outstanding, regardless of discipline. A lot of young progressive thinkers.
Cons: Benefits are somewhat average to below average, however salary is competitive or superior. Matching RSP and share purchase plan is below average. Nothing that cannot be compensated for during your initial negotiation.
Advice to Management: Update your benefits package to be more aligned with industry standards. 4% match, 2%SPP match and more sick/floater days. Keep lines of communication open up and down the chain of command. Invest in your employees they are your greatest asset. Keep the integrity and honesty, it is appreciated by employees at all levels. Communicate communicate, communicate!

Met some really nice people there and learnt a lot from the more mature and experienced people. The head office is really nice and modern, so working conditions were good. Benefits aren't the best but they are not bad and every month or two there are social nights where the staff enjoy a great night out to socialise with their colleagues, often subsidised by the company.
Cons: Opportunities for growth and progression are available only if you are able to put the extra effort in. I was working 45+ hours a week (contract 37.5) and still not good enough, it is frowned upon if you get off your seat at 5pm! The large projects and on site offices means moving locations and working with different staff all the time.
Advice to Management: Try to inject a better work life balance in to your business and value your employees more as they are your business.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: -Managers purposely not assisting your career development, denying you transfers to other department or going to WSP workshops or lessons as constantly short on staff -High pressure environment, managers have no time to focus on your own growth in company and more focused on deadlines -Extremely bad work life balance caused at least two or three colleagues emotional breakdowns within months -Extremely high turnover, approx. 10 left in one year out of 60 people in department -No initial training provided, graduates have to train other graduates -Low pay for central London (£22k for graduates)  -Occasional upper management refusal of pay raise or bonuses with no explanation offered -Lack of diversity in upper management, project managers and above are all Caucasian, around 60-70% were men in business for 10+ years
