evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP grew extremely quickly and inorganically by acquiring / merging some of the largest engineering consultancies in Canada and the United States. Corporate leadership has expressed that it is time to begin in its people. To focus on performance, talent, and the organic growth of teams through skilled hires.
Cons: The issue will continue to be retaining top talent. On one hand WSP takes pride in providing opportunities to contribute to some of the world's largest projects, but it would seem that its best and brightest do not stay for long.  Starting salaries do not attract top talent, and new grads are attracted to WSP's size and global brand - something WSP will rely on to attract a large number of applicants, but perhaps not the premium candidates they are looking for.  On-boarding process is virtually non-existent. Team managers within offices are left to their own devices. The next few years will be key for WSP to set its new course on an internal trajectory that streamlines processes and supports the top talent that has carried the company through its current transition phase.
Advice to Management: Invest in your people. Start understanding why mid-level and senior employees are leaving. On-boarding process for all new employees is needed to make everyone feel part of the global team.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Fantastic line manager Very good systems in place for support  Given a lot of responsibility and ownership quickly  Varied training opportunities Team leader had a lot of time and trust for graduates.
Cons: Not much variety of work, often end up stuck on one project, or end up with a 'specialism' you can't shake Due to the merge the process for promotions and reviews was changed without training for line managers or info for employees. Very unclear. This may have changed.  A lot of junior staff are often lumped with admin tasks such as formatting documents for senior staff with a lack of basic IT skills.  PGN is great but often a way for senior management to get graduates to do extra work for no recognition or reward.
Advice to Management: Recognise the achievements of your team. Ensure ALL line managers make time for their direct reportees. Private regular meetings are essential.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP provide a lot of opportunities for employees to progress their education, as well as supporting them through professional reviews. Whether you are an apprentice or graduate, WSP will give you the flexibility to study on your preferred part-time course, or facilitate the experience you require to fulfil professional membership criteria such as IEng.    - Opportunity to further your education and professional achievements  - WSP employ people in almost every sector of the Engineering and Construction industries. Take advantage of the skills set around you and learn something new.  - The way in which we carry out our day to day tasks is forever evolving. WSP provide their employees with access to the latest software packages used in every discipline.
Cons: - Staff rewards  - Salary  - Poorly run Apprenticeship scheme (This is beginning to improve). - Slow progress in the use of BIM in certain disciplines

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP care about their employees. Employees are very skilled. HR & other support stuffs are very helpful. Salary scale is much better than other players in the industry like AECOM, COWI, RAMBOLL, MOTT McDONAD etc. You will have opportunity to grow with the company & most of all every person in the group are easily achievable. Nice place to work.
Cons: If you are in UK or US or Sweden team, then nothing to worry. But if you are in Middle-East team then you have to worry about your job all the time. And the working time of the team is pathetic. But you will get well paid for OT as well as they provide dinner.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Big company, access to colleagues around the world
Cons: Bad management, bad culture. Quality of projects don’t matter, cheap & fast is the mantra.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: At WSP Parsons Brinckerhoff, there is always a friendly atmosphere to welcome all current and new employees. The company is a leading multi discipline organisation.
Cons: Such as the size of the company, and with occupations covering all levels from apprentice to associate, it can slow or stunt the development of certain individuals.
Advice to Management: My advice to management would be to not judge an individual by their held qualifications or age when it comes to their salary, but rather their experience e.g. an employee without a degree,but has a HNC, who has been an employee for a number of years with experience, will often have a much lower salary then that of a new graduate with no experience. I'm aware the majority of graduate salaries are government funded but the salary gap needs to be reduced as well as employees being offered a competitive salary.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: - Brand new office, well thoughtout open space - many new hires - Huge cafe - Amazing HR advisors and recruiters
Cons: - 90% of the employees are arrogant / desk monkeys - very corporate work environment ( no sense of team building what so ever) - fairly low paid salary and minimum vacation (EIT salary $55k and 2 weeks of vacation and no bonus)  - poor team and environment that led to low morale in the office - after 10-15 years of EIT/ Technical experience you may or may not move into a management position - there were Engineers in their 40s with no management role or experience  - very poor methods of providing criticism, a current employee had comments such as “you women, I am not sure what your guys are even good at” and “ I am never hiring from Ryerson again”
Advice to Management: Hire for personality and knowledge not arrogance and "geeky knowledge". Knowledge like that can be learned or taught but you should look to involve all the employees into doing good work and building better team spirit. I know at least 3 (out of total of 6 EITs) other EITs currently looking to leave.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: - Great group of work friends and a collection of different personalities. They'll never make a TV -sitcom about an engineering office, but it still a positive environment. - Mostly interesting project work and variety, but you never knew what was coming down the pike.
Cons: - Poor work scheduling meant I was often working on projects that required 60-70hr per week, while the person across from me only needed to work 40-50. - Very easy to get pigeon-holed into a very specific project type and do the same thing over and over. - High competition for work meant that engineering services were becoming more generic and commoditized, instead of client-specific.
Advice to Management: - Develop your young people. In my office the average age was well above 40 and there wasn't enough focus on building up young employees to take over management.

evaluation: Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: There used to be many pros unfortunately now I am hard pressed to find one pro.
Cons: Previous CEO was trying to change the company onto an oil and gas company and had no regard for the engineering side. Many disgruntled employees, the sense of work as a team is completely gone and no one even talks to each other anymore.  The change in Sr mgmt had helped tremendously especially in the Transportation and Infrastructure side, however I am inclined to believe too much damage has been done and it will be a long road to recovery.   All of the employee benefits (bonuses, perks etc) that were once in place are all gone now and there is no incentives for employees to stay.  The HSE and HR teams are both under horrible leadership. Specifically HSE, the leadership is extremely poor, leadership in this group tends to sit on items far too long and the HSE staff are treated extremely poorly. HR tends to sweep any concerns under the rug and they are never dealt with.  This is not a company I would ever recommend working for unless the new CEO makes swift changes.
Advice to Management: A long road to recovery ahead of you. If changes are not made you are bound to lose alot of employees once the economy bounces back.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: From the initial contact with the recruitment team until today when I am celebrating my 10 months with the company, it has been a great journey. The whole process of bringing me on board was smooth despite the legal hardships of relocating on a short notice. Everything was handled with professionalism and I was kept informed at all times , which made me feel I was already part of WSP even before meeting my team. I am proud of my company's reputation, I get the support I need for my development, I get to work with some brilliant people and have made some good friends along the way. All in all, i feel that WSP is a great place to work.
Cons: - Not Applicable - .

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: I had joined as a fresher in Fire Protection Services team and spend more than a year. I learnt so many things but not happy with line manager policy even no body in team is happy because he didn't give equal opportunity to share their experience as well as problems.
Cons: Their policy is not good because i was working from more than a year and one day in evening they said we don't have work and we are reducing our team and another hand they are recruiting the more peoples.  I never give advice to anyone to join WSP because it happened 2 times while my tenure and now also i am suffering.
Advice to Management: Share the exact issue with employee not only with line manager because might be line manager gives you wrong information due to miss communication.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Management promote from outside so great place to get a job. Lots of opportunities for those selected. Few highly dedicated technical professionals, so lots of opportunities to rise.  Values the inexperienced especially at mid level management.
Cons: Driven by bottom line, so those with project management speak do well. Office is nearly empty at 4 pm so excellent work life balance, except the few dedicated technical proficient individuals who work long hours. So be careful not to become one of those.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: I was part of the building science team. Energetic and driven young group; many smart engineers; CEO was from the former MMM and seemed approachable and wise.
Cons: Still a strong culture of legacy company at the Yonge/Eglinton office; company is constantly acquiring so constant change but very poor communication from leadership about decisions - they communicate matters after they happen so you don't feel part of the company; boys club and have hard time listening to women; no diversity in the office makes for an ignorant group who does not welcome those who don't fit a mold; aggressive and arrogant engineering mentality; i'm pretty sure i wasn't paid accurately; benefits were standard nothing special. too many men at the top.
Advice to Management: engineers need leadership training so they can develop interpersonal skills. there is more to work than grinding through the work; work atmosphere counts and it trickles from the top down; this office and group did not have effective leadership. take note from MMM culture - by far the best I have seen in consulting.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook
Pros: - One of the best building consultants (brands, standards, work qualities, project portfolios) - If can manage time well, 9-5 working period with very rare overtime is possible - Conducive environment to learn as fresh graduate - Encourages a lot of learning and training - Many welfare activities and incentives - No/less working politics
Cons: - The pay is relatively low, even as compared with other consultants (starting pay at $2900, have not changed for 2 years) - No overtime pay (only meal/transport if really late) - Very few company benefits & compensations - High staff turnover (expect 2 new staffs per week)
Advice to Management: - The salary need to adjusted accordingly to minimize staff turnover

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Variety of projects Access to Experts Depending on the team the culture would be either good or bad As with a lot of the engineering industry years of experience counts most than individual performance Acquisition by WSP has given a boost to the morale
Cons: Salary disparities within same positions New hires could be paid more than employees who've been with the company for long Opportunities to diversify the skills are limited
Advice to Management: The disparities of salary within the same position is something needs to be addressed.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Large amount of services and resources available to you internally, 75-100% benefits plan, RRSP matching etc. Lots of opportunity depending how you function in a larger organization.
Cons: Still working out bugs getting everyone trained onto common as well as newly developed workflows after worldwide rebranding, To be fair, it likely has been smooth all things considered.
Advice to Management: Get through the rebranding, Hard to take seriously until you cut loose the out of touch excess baggage from all these acquisitions, and start acting, or let those trying to, put some substance behind the all this future ready marketing. Catering to the old just feels hypocritical at this point.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great projects (but you often don't get to work on them) Great opportunities (if you happen to be in the right place when people above are forcibly removed or are given poorly thought-out promotions i.e. depending on which way the wind blows) Good coffee machines and copious free booze Seems to be backed by an endless pot of gold somewhere
Cons: If you're looking to stay longer than 18 months, you'll likely experience: Very unstable management structures Unstable leadership Very poor support to project managers Ridiculous disparity between offices A laser-like focus on mega-projects, which comes at the expense of anything else Very confused messaging from management, that alternates between 'we're going under/redundancies' and 'things have never been better/give anyone walking by a job' - sometimes in the same day
Advice to Management: Stick to a plan for longer than 12 months

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good work-life balance with reasonable wages
Cons: Not the same... I hope to retire in a few years rather than stay on part-time because of the change in the culture, especially since expanding. This billion dollar company has nickel and dimed their way out of even giving their employees the year end Christmas party. Now you have to pay for it. More and more I overhear and have seen employees being intimated and bullied by bad eggs and management who seem to absolutely love it, especially if the worker desperately needs their job.. the insecure games never end... then pretend to be astonished when they quit... it is beyond sick. In a few years I won't need to work so I am not going to continue and will take my years of experience with me.
Advice to Management: Overhaul some of your managers into sessions on employee retention. The trick isn't to hire someone the trick is to keep them.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: I love working here, I generally find everyone to be really nice. we re a group of passionate people who do what we do because we love it. Engineers as a group can be a quiet and conservative types in the main so it can be quiet but once you get to know everyone I have found most people really nice, helpful and friendly.   Working for a large company is good, at times we could probably communicate a little better, but the information is out there, it is on us to read it.
Cons: There are no cons for me,

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Flexible work hours. Pay is decent. Get to interact with worldwide engineers team directly. That's it.
Cons: Learning and Growth are negligible. Don't come if you're an engineer. Management needs training on how to manage team. A lot of partiality. You do good on one project and next the moment you find yourself shifted on other project by your manager, he cannot handle your growth. No designing work for engineers. Only revit or CAD work that too which requires a lot of manual labour and not your experience. You don't need a Bachelor's Degree to do that. Seriously. Period.   This office of WSP in India is set up only to support other offices worldwide with their Revit or CAD work. Design work is only restricted to schedules preparing and lighting calcs, that too a part of the project that they cannot do because of time limitations.   WSP engineers doesn't trust Indian Engineers for their engineering capabilities.   Well, if you understand what I mean then maybe I have saved one person's career. And frustrated unlimited.
Advice to Management: Read the cons and work on it.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Big company. Great opportunities for career development, even more now that Parsons Brinckerhoff has merged with WSP. Many offices in the UK and abroad. Large investments in graduates. Training accredited by IMechE, IET, ICE, etc.
Cons: The salary is in the average of UK salaries for graduates, but it could be a bit higher. The three year graduate programme is quite long compared to other companies and not well structured yet
Advice to Management: I would suggest to put in place a better structured graduate programme. However,I am aware that after the merging with WSP, action has been taken in this terms and a well defined graduate scheme will be in place soon

evaluation: No opinion of CEO
Pros: The parent company appears to have growth potential and vision for the future.
Cons: Health and safety did not exist! First day told to stand up wind of manway, due to H2S and personal monitor was broken and being repaired.  Had not rescue plan for confined space entry for removal of underground storage tank. Was working alone and had to enter via ladder into unshored excavation- all sand.   One of hotesst summers, working alone, samplin. Ground water wells, 4 purge system ( meaning lifting 60 lbs per well; 50 wells; while carrying coolers and containers through woods) NO heat stress policy or safety; realized I stopped sweating and had stomach cramps. Hide in shade for 2 hours. Asked about heat and cold stress manager did not even know what I meant!  Operating 4x4 ATV no training, loading into small trailer that was no licensed or inspected road worthy.  Out of town work, suppose to be for the day, again heat stress... Also fumes from old gas station in air, no respirators or safety plan, open excavation

evaluation: Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP provides an extensive range of consulting services throughout the world and there is good communication and information exchange between the offices affording excellent opportnities for growth for its younger employees.
Cons: There are in fact very few downsides, but it was noted that whilst opportunities for growth are encouraged among its younger employees, they are less apparent for older employees.
Advice to Management: Whilst WSP has excellent facilities and opportunities for professional development of its younger staff, it would be useful if the older staff who are not at director level could also be provided with similar levels of opportunities.

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: The company takes care of you well. I'm an apprentice and they are paying for me to study at university once a week towards my degree in Civil engineering. Pensions and health care are great.
Cons: Pay is ok considering that they are paying for my degree. Would like a faster route as the process is many years. Only one apprentice joined the same time as me and the rest are a lot older.
Advice to Management: Put forward schemes to fast track apprentices or shadow the director of the office. It would provide a good experience and will show them the higher up responsibilities.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Creative environment Helpful Colleagues Line Managers ensure you are engaged Challenging projects that get you thinking beyond the basic theory taught at university
Cons: Need to show an interest, otherwise, you may be ideal. You also have to be cautious how you approach this, which makes it a little more complicated than it should be
Advice to Management: As a senior colleague at the firm mentioned, even if there are tasks which interns may not be able to take on due to the length, complexity and dedication required for the project, a system where past or imaginary projects can be used to develop interns or new graduates could prove useful.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: What we got paid and how we got paid was great, always on time! Wonderful learning experience. Very good communication with us, always received reminders, hints on how to do a better job, and always someone there to help us out even after being on the field. Would love to work there again anytime!!!
Cons: Really can not find significant cons. Every job and company has them but I just can not seem to pinpoint any at this time.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: It's a professional company. People get respect from both the company and each other. And you would have chance to make contribution with you capacities and experience.
Cons: For technical staff, they should not be recognized only because they have some sort of centificates on hand and don't have real professional experience. And too many supporting staff in supporting departments, both in local office and headoffice.
Advice to Management: Employee survey may only get rough feedbacks from staff. Suggest senior management to spend time to talk to mid lever or even general staff to get first hand feedback.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP is a great place to work at the people are very helpful and everyone works as team to get the job done and service the client as best as possible
Cons: due to acquisitions and mergers that have taken place, there are many people that felt like they either wanted to move on or had to
Advice to Management: Do whatever is needed to keep the senior people.they are very knowledgable and once they are let go or quit are very hard to replace .there have been situations where people have followed them out the door further hurting the company

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great work-life balance, fantastic opportunities to work in a range of different sectors, good IT support and clear company values. Great place to start your career in Engineering sector, great range of experience in staff.
Cons: Development can become static if not proactive. Lack of opportunity to progress upwards. Graduate programme questionable for those outside of main disciplines (e.g Structures).
Advice to Management: Graduate programme should be looked at in more detail - particularly for those who are graduate individuals that are not in contact with other graduates. People outside of the main disciplines can be forgotten.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Quality Pay Quality Product Excellent Work-Life balance. Despite the company size, the workgroups operate as if they are still smaller teams and feels close-knit.
Cons: The company has grown too fast for their own good, and are lacking in standards Despite the company size, the workgroups operate as if they are still smaller teams (This is also a con because there is so much potential for work-sharing that is being lost)
Advice to Management: Figure out a way to make our large-scale operations much more efficient so that work efforts are not being duplicated.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Interesting place to work at. Management reach out to staff to help them understand what is needed for them to fufill their role.
Cons: Pay package could be improve. Although they maintain the market rate, it is no sufficient to maintain good staff when other companies are willing to pay higher amount of salary to them.
Advice to Management: Overall it is a good company to work at. however if salary can be adjusted, it will be better. Taking the average of national salary for engineers are good but there are always higher paying company.

evaluation: Recommends, Approves of CEO
Pros: The level of talent in the engineering department is higher than other consulting firms I have been associated with. Management has been responsive to my needs and questions. Being hired in at a mid-level, I have noticed that promotions generally come from within and are performance based.
Cons: At times I feel we are a tad understaffed. However, if overtime is necessary, we are compensated.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: my office is well situated in the town, good working conditions and nice people - the company is recovering well after a few years of redundancies and is working well to uphold the company visions and values
Cons: WSP's national and international status means lots of opportunities for staff to change jobs or move around meaning very little consistancy of work/staff in postions.
Advice to Management: WSP needs better consistancy of work company wide - we need to find a high level of work and ALL follow this...

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Nice people, considerate, lots of room to move up and advance, global so possible to move countries, well structured.
Cons: Work can be monotonous, pay is not the best - but not the worst either, expectations of work quality are a little high for the time given to complete work.
Advice to Management: Continue doing a good job, listen to your employees and try your best to accommodate them, either with moving within the company, moving office or giving them time to complete tasks.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good degree of autonomy and transparency for job activities. Good IT support and intranet maintenance. Turn-over rate is towards the lower end of industry range.
Cons: Promotion and remuneration depends on who you rub shoulder with and who have more exposure. Lacking the sense of belonging.
Advice to Management: To rate staffs with what they can do and what they wish to do, on top of what they have done. Need to cultivate a culture that include openness, fairness and tolerance.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Started with small company environment & culture with the GRB side. Excellent work culture and people. The company in general valued its employees.
Cons: When GRB was combined with Tundra into one building, the culture morphed and it became a popularity contest. Tundra had more employees to begin with so they influenced who was to be ousted. It became a bit "cut-throat" and "survival of the fittest" kind of work culture unfortunately. To make matters worse, the parent company bought Focus so off course there were too much overlap. Then to top it off the sharp drop in oil/gas commodity price.
Advice to Management: Try not to be a typical reactionary consulting firm where you layoff so many people after "swallowing more than you could chew".

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Diversified and positive working environment. Flexible hours and good work/life balance. Knowledgeable engineers and managers across all disciplines. Senior managers are approachable, technically prepared and open minded. Very interesting multidisciplinary projects. Culture of `working as a team` with little internal competition.
Cons: Poor yearly bonus. Internal processes could be improved. Not much Company social life outside work.
Advice to Management: Focus on hire qualified graduates to increase delivery quality.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Very knowledgeable mentors, great office environment, plenty of social activities, professional and organized.
Cons: Some individuals feel more entitled then they should with the knowledge and capability that they have (I expect that you would see this at any company).
Advice to Management: Try to encorporate a program where people that put in a noticeably larger amount of work/effort can be nominated and recognized. The effort from each person around the office does not seem to be very consistent.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: My first job and possibly my last love working for WSP.  They are willing to listen to you and allow you to make your own path.  They encourage travel inter company and you can virtually pick anywhere on the planet to work and we have an office.
Cons: Due to the corporate Nate of the business we do seam to have a lot of boards.  Can be hard to stand out with so many incredibly talented people around.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: open environment, reasonable salary, great leader, I can learn a lot from the team and contribution will be recognized.
Cons: the workload is sometimes high, in some months, i need to work over time to finish my project in time, and the working pressure is high
Advice to Management: Provide more free time for the employee to grow up, provide more training and resources to the employee to help them build up their skills needed.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Option of working from home; company benefits, for example, car scheme, ability to buy Apple products through your salary, medical cover, etc; bonuses; awards; a great attitude towards H&S; approachable management.
Cons: Some positions require a large amount of travelling worldwide; many are unable to complete tasks in a normal working week so end up working in our own time.
Advice to Management: Reviews on working hours should be taking place on a regular basis.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great opportunity to work on high profile projects. Good experience with management and great community within MMM. Supportive teams willing to help each other out.
Cons: Difficult to get technical job experience in a junior engineer position working in a project management, project specific, role. Recommend new engineering hires work on a technical team in order to gain the necessary technical experience to become effective project managers later on in their careers.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Good international project experience. you get best work station to work and IT and other support staff are very helpful.Timely salary. Overall WSP India except Sweden civil team is one of the good company to work in india.
Cons: Lack of experience and zero decision making skill in Sweden team. I have been working more than 1 year in team still avg utilization is 50-60%. they are randomly hiring people . If you want join sweden team than be prepare yourself that you will get any work for next 6 month. It is very simple to work with Sweden country but management is making complicated way of working and in the end India is not getting any project from Sweden

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Large Company to spread out workload Small specialty teams that make it feel like a smaller company
Cons: Cramped working space Salary freezes possible, merit increases are small, promotion does not seem to exist at non management level
Advice to Management: People seem to be stagnant in title, salary. Small merit increases and lack of promotion do not provide motivation for oneself or others to strive for success.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: -Great place to develop technical expertise in various building services (Fire Protection; Plumbing & Sanitary; HVAC)  -Great place to develop contacts in the building/construction industry
Cons: -Culture of working late (certain divisions); seniors/project managers call for discussions just before knock-off time. Workload is far too high for project managers, which spills over to junior staff.  -Unsympathetic, results-oriented boss(es)  -Unattractive salary package; little medical benefits; size of bonus is a bit of a joke; no 13th month.
Advice to Management: PB is a great place to be (most of the time); the work is meaningful and the results are tangible, but the sometimes toxic work environment, deeply ingrained culture of working late, and noncompetitive salary/benefits package makes for poor staff morale/retention. There has to be a reason why employee turnover is high. Could do better.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The people are great fun and, generally, friendly - there is a good social scene. Work is varied and you get involved in good, high-profile projects. Starting salaries for graduates are similar to that of other companies.
Cons: Unfortunately junior staff (in the environmental side of the business, at least) do not get paid very well compared to other companies as they progress.
Advice to Management: Work on rewarding staff you want to retain!

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: - Colleagues include industry leaders, and all are helpful and supportive of those starting their careers - Opportunities to work on both big and small projects - Currently seem to be winning more work than their competitors
Cons: - Currently top-heavy, so limited career progression - HR and employee development programs/networks are in disarray. Some good components, but drowning in bureaucracy. Throw it all out, start again.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Supportive at a local level, diverse company, interesting work, relocation a possibility if you are willing to ask for it perhaps
Cons: faceless, organisation too large, feel like a number, decisions made by ceo have no impact on day to day work
Advice to Management: be more personable, relate to people at the local level, be more open and less 'politically correct', communicate more often and not just about the share price or EBITDA

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Great company vibe and sense of vision / purpose regarding sustainability, innovative designs and great outcomes for clients.
Cons: Work could be fever-pitch to meet deadlines and after acquisition by WSP (formerly the business was Lincolne Scott) somewhat lost focus. Still a great business though and would recommend.
Advice to Management: Focus on delivering a great, innovative culture - and finding the next "new ideas" as sustainability drove the business through the 2000s

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Depending on the location, the best feature of the company is the smart, innovative and talented colleagues who are good at their job and fun to associate with outside of work
Cons: extensive corporate restructuring can affect quality of work and quality of life for employees depending on which region you work for. given that it is a global company this is more true for some offices than others.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: A trusting environment, allowing employees huge flexibility with a great focus on getting it right for the client and letting the rest fall into place. A large company though, where many different departments operate in different ways.
Cons: This is a large, disparate company, with many skills in many industries. Working together in global multi-disciplinary teams is a challenge to such a company.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: There are some good people. Office within range of public transport Friday morning BBQ's Reasonable work life balance
Cons: WSP in Au is basically the takeover of Lincoln Scott. Whilst its called WSP, it doesnt run like a typically engineering consultancy. It lacks processes and often management is not people that are good at managing they are simply people who have been promoted through attaining high sales targets. This makes it difficult to attain change. Salaries tend to lag the market slightly, especially if you have come in from another country. Most foreign staff are often underpaid in my opinion.
Advice to Management: Its time to start following the market and getting much more structured about how business is undertaken. Accountability is lacking. Ethics in business practise could do with an overhaul.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: 1. The company pays well.  2. EDO (earn day off) program is awesome - works out to almost every second Friday off based on working 9 hours per day (1 of 8 hours is banked).  3. Very casual environment.   4. Currently there are excellent VP's working for the company (not including HR). Good leadership goes a long way.  5. Company is flexible on work hours. Good work/life balance  6. Good benefits
Cons: Where to start...  1. HR team desperately needs to go! Not too many things worse then those who condone double standards.   2. Due to the economy downturn the company is struggling to bring in new projects - this is also due to being too expensive when bidding proposals.  3. Lots of staff turnover and lots of instances of blind-siding layoffs. As well as switch & bait layoffs - i.e switching someone's currently role to someone else's role who is planned to be laid off while the other person (being laid off) has no clue.  4. Many PM's and Engineers do not follow general PM practices  5. Lack of company training and ongoing education of the company culture - i.e something is rolled out but then never really brought up again. As well as a definite clash of PMO mapping.  6. The company has gone from a smaller EPCM firm to merging with the corporate division and is currently still suffering many growing pain since 2015. The company, on many levels is nowhere near ready for these types of big adjustment and/or unwilling to accept change.  7. Facilities Manager also needs to desperately go! Not sure how it's considered productive when it takes up to 1-2 weeks to get back to people or not at all. Or dropping last requests/tasks on people expecting them to drop and stop everything they're doing just for you and just because you dropped the ball. Or getting your hair done during business hours. Or talking trash about your team and/or other employees in general. Or simply lying about various things.  Fortunately not everything about the company is horrible however these types of actions from this particular individual does absolutely nothing good for company on many levels.
Advice to Management: Put more emphasis on the PMO structure and continuous training. Pay far more attention to the lack of PM practices and those who neglect. Replace HR and the Facilities Manager.

evaluation: Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Most of stuff is very friendly and supportive
Cons: No training support for graduates. Low salaries. Some time unfair decision from director level with no clear reason. They make people redundant same time they give promotion, pay rise and external training to some staff in the same department,  United by difference is the tag line used by the company earlier this year; which fits perfectly fine for profit sharing and playing politics.. Management take care of senior staff and shareholder more than new and recent graduate. Join if you want to distroy your career.
Advice to Management: Leadership of WSP is not going to listen so no point in giving advice to them. They still live in 19th centure where they think china and india(along with other commonwealth countries) are poor third world countrie and discrimenate people from these countries. You can't wake up a person who is actually not sleeping. There is a big communication gap between management and employees.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Great team, competitive salary, good resources (work tools, access to experts in many fields), management is approachable, technical teams have lots of autonomy. Flexible hours.
Cons: Tedious administrative procedures, not adapted to fast paced sectors with lots of small projects. Company takes itself a bit too seriously, pushing the brand on employees at every opportunity. High expectations for productivity, sometimes unrealistic timelines.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: WSP has a nice work culture, teams are supportive and is driven by values of trust, passion, innovation, etc. WSP has good infrastructure and provides ample opportunities to learn and grow.
Cons: Some of the issues which are prevalent in large size MNCs could be there in WSP as well.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great salaries, bonuses and project uplift Plenty of autonomy Opportunity to shine if you work hard
Cons: Felt like just a number or revenue stream Do not feel part of the wider business No future work as too engineering focused in my region
Advice to Management: Harness the talent you have to help you win the next job

evaluation: NULL
Pros: Global Company, so there is an opportunity to transfer to a foreign office if you desire. There is a strong sense of community within teams, people in the business are mostly very friendly. The graduate scheme is slowly changing with better opportunities for graduates to get a more holistic experience of the whole company by being able to rotate to other parts of the business and also the team building exercises with other graduates from all parts of the business.
Cons: There seems to be a sparing amount of work within teams, where graduates especially do not get enough challenging work to do. There is poor organisational structure within the some of the teams, with seemingly uninspiring engineers. The salary is very mediocre.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Flexible attitude if you have personal/family obligations You can work on you own, no micromanaging Plenty of work and good technical support  Free pop/juice/ Kerig coffee
Cons: With the expansion of the company the camaraderie has disappeared, the diversity too as positions are more specialized as it increases the bottom line. Office bullying is becoming a norm throughout the differing offices and is encouraged or even instigated by management, you really have to watch your back.  I've been here for years and it used to be a dream job with great people but now I'm sorry to say to someone job searching - hit the ground running the opposite way!
Advice to Management: Teamwork begins and ends with management.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: * Great Offices. * Great Staff (generally). * Very Social. * Very Focussed - some excellent projects.
Cons: * I.T Management lacking focus. * Senior I.T staff do not assist new starters. * Zero Mentoring. * Poor Communication.
Advice to Management: * Please listen more to people in the West.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: - International company that is constantly growing; acquired several large engineering services companies around the world - Involved in many large and exciting projects across the world - Many opportunities for people who are looking to make a big impact
Cons: - Old-fashioned company and average age of employees in company is above 40 - Slow processes  - Not many company events/benefits

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Coworkers are friendly and diligent, and supervisor listens to our needs and provides reasonable demands. Balance of working independently on our projects and in small groups. Some variety in clients and processes in sites, resulting in different problems to solve or look for in each site
Cons: Work load is inconsistent in the Shanghai office at least. Depending on your skill set, i.e. Health & Safety or Environmental, soil sampling and analysis or compliance, workloads can be high or low. Hard to truly progress due to this issue.
Advice to Management: As the EHS division was fairly independent, perhaps help out in business development and finding more clients and projects. Provide clearer path for progression in skills and benefits.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Great co-workers, decent benefits, good experience
Cons: Pyramid management structure is designed to be cost effective, but when mid and senior engineers leave, there is a huge knowledge gap. Lots of young talent but not very much structure or technical supervision/support.
Advice to Management: Better pay, more recognition, better technical support for drafting and project management, and a better follow through on promises.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: Great people who work hard. Great benefits - one of the best I have seen and always looking for ways to improve. Value work/life balance.
Cons: I worked there for a few yrs and the company grew quicker than it could keep up. More focus on current staff and programs but I believe they are moving in the right direction.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Reasonable immediate management and hours as junior consultants. Projects were meaningful with clear purpose and results. Able to travel across country and see variety of industrial sites. 15 days paid leave plus national holidays.
Cons: Work loads were uneven, either feast or famine. Unclear career progression as semi-expat.
Advice to Management: None really, position was unusual as an entry-level expat.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Large organisation with great people and culture. Nice offices. Global scale so great for overseas exposure. There are lots of innovative forums and good social committee
Cons: The ERP very out of date leading to inefficiencies but in track for change and improvement.  Growth by acquisition so lots more standardisation needed and some areas still very much in old structure silos

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook
Pros: Growing fast, young senior management. Working with outher employees accross Canada.
Cons: In Atlantic Canada there is no room to grow any further in your career. Work is slow and there are no interesting projects to work on. The work is not challenging and I am board most days. I haven't learned anything new since working here and I feel disconnected from the company. Most days I feel I'm bashing my head against a wall.
Advice to Management: If people show a passion for their work and are excited about building their group to help the company, let them run with it and take a chance. Stop putting up road blocks. You should make it easier for them not harder.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Nice people, not too busy and a lot to learn
Cons: Since I didn't stay too long I'm not sure what it's like to work for a long term. But it was quite boring when I was working at the office
Advice to Management: A fairly good job. Perhaps it's boring just because I was not interested to this industry

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook

Advice to Management: Provide benefits, other than salary that retains the best talent and makes employees feel appreciated

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

Advice to Management: Adapt or die. Don't be afraid of restructure to connect employees to their 'internal clients' as market demand shifts.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Interesting oil and gas projects  Stable  Decent benifits Pay OK Still a few great senior engineers willing to mentor jr/int engineers
Cons: New management doesn't have a clue how to run a successful engineering firm. Very shortsighted with only being concerned about the bottom line and not providing solutions to clients or healthy environment for employees. No concept of paying employees for performance.
Advice to Management: Stop being selfish and only worrying about your bonus. Happy employees are productive employees, productive employees will create business, with business comes profits, with profits comes bonuses, everyone wins.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: NULL
Pros: Work is primarily for private industry, very few public sector clients. There is a diversity of project types, and most project managers are very good.
Cons: As with any consulting firm, the constant juggling of conflicting priorities and deadlines is a burden. In the US, the company is transitioning from from small, privately owned firm to part of a large public firm. Senior staff seem to be stuck at current level with little opportunity for promotion or further challenge.
Advice to Management: Accept the fact that growth is a now a requirement, make adjustments to accomplish this, and get to it.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Lean organization. Great entrepreneurial spirit.
Cons: Integrations poorly done. Lack of communication. Staff feel isolated particularly when a smaller team joins a larger team . Lack of systems and processes. Constant turnover of lower to mid staff. Integration of MMM was a disaster. Large exodus of staff from numerous offices. Departure of key staff (including senior WSP managers) in 2017 due to poor communication and poor integration plan. New managers did little to welcome\integrate staff. Too many silos.
Advice to Management: Improve basic communication. Develop integration plans for future acquisitions. Lack of culture due to many silos.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Big name, job security and good projects. The offices are decent. pay reviews are carried out annually. Generally a flexible approach to employees.
Cons: Size of the organisation leaves you feeling like a very small cog in a very large machine. Bonuses are small.

evaluation: None

evaluation: None

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: There are absolutely no pros what so ever about this company. Their offices are out of date and grimy. The interview was the most professional ever. But from day one there, I was treated with utter discontent. Pathetic. No stars.
Cons: Everything imaginable about the place. It took two weeks to get the computer to work. The brand new hire boss had no management skills whatsoever. He yelled at me from day one. Insulted my country of origin, my language my dialect, my educational credentials, my writing skills, my existence.
Advice to Management: Don't fire some who has been harassed and keep the inept novice boss who has exactly two weeks of experience as a manager. That is actually immorale. Btw send him to management charm school and teach him some employment law.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Great offices. Stable. Comfortable environment. All needs are satisfied in order to work efficiently. Colleagues are easy to talk to and look out for one another.
Cons: Salary is quite low for the level of skilled work done. There is little to no parking. Very short sighted future for employees. Day in and day out activities are the same.
Advice to Management: Allow staff to have an insight into their future. If no future is possible for the staff, at least be honest in informing the staff members where their peak in the company will be

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: No company can keep doubling in size every few years and maintain continuity in quality of work and a productive stable working environment.  Inability to win sufficient work due to the absence of locals in senior management. Very corporate and stifling work environment.
Advice to Management: Get an Emirati leader and some fresh blood in senior management.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook
Pros: The wider WSP | Parsons Brinckerhoff company has some very experienced and knowledgeable experts and is involved in some cutting edge infrastructure projects.
Cons: The Energy & Industry business unit in the UK is set up for a previous era and no longer seems to match the requirements of the market. Management seems to be stuck in a rut and no amount of restructuring seems to make any difference.
Advice to Management: Focus more on clients' needs, match resources to the needs of the market and actively break down internal silos (competence and geographical).

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Basic insurance / perks. During the summer, on Fridays we can leave at noon if our hours are done.
Cons: Vacation time is only 2 weeks - which is nothing when you factor in the christmas days you're forced to take (between 25th and the 1st) - we have access to the WSP employee portal globally, we can see how much more vacation our european counter-parts get. It's demoralizing.
Advice to Management: Improve your vacation policy. When a team kills itself on a large project, maybe some of that bonus money should get to the team itself.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: Great people to work with, overall good work conditions

Leadership should update their people management philosophy, for example by allowing for flexible schedules, working from home, workspace that consider employee needs and not just fitting as many people as possible on each floor, standing or sitting desks, etc.  Currently focus seems to be on maximizing revenue for investors more than making sure employees are happy at work and receive competitive compensation and perks.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: You get the chance of working on great, big, complex and challenging projects. The company is well organised at corporate/business level.
Cons: - Some people are pigeonholed and do only certain tasks, not alowed to expand knowledge and responsibilities; It takes many years for a graduate to accumulate engineering knowledge. - Senior engineers are not allowed to do project management or own the project as most of the responsibilities are kept at the top.  - I constantly had to jump from highly focused problem-solving tasks to the big picture or from project to project and because of that, visibility was next to zero and the environment highly stressful. When you were trying to delegate you had to burn the budget just on training the staff but then immediately bullied. - From trainee technicians to Principal/Senior Engineers you were expected to execute the project managers' design/technical decisions the only difference being in how fast you do it. Because of that, the turnover for Senior Engineers was really high. - Very stressful, low life-work balance and low career progression opportunities due to the extreme boxed/silo environment.  - The worst part ever was that everyone was working on everything depending on their availability, training and knowledge didn't have time to sediment and because people had different working styles there were endless mistakes, quality of final projects poor and delivery chaotic.  - You had no idea what you'll do next week but were constantly under the pressure to deliver. - The communication was either too extreme or too low and due to high stress, some people were very grumpy and unhelpful, doing more harm than good.  - Sometimes departments were acting like in a zero-sum game where everyone fought for resources and power. - The staff was either too stressed, undertrained, underbudgeted, unled and because some felt used as machines, motivation was poor and credibility in management undermined.  - If you're technically sharp you never get promoted and your salary never increases; they only consider you a better horse and if you're cheap, you can easily become everybody's horse.  - the management was constantly making empty promises and were sugar coating me. - too many meetings and emails were burning the budget.
Advice to Management: Sediment knowledge and responsibilities in departments, break the silos, be concerned over your staffs' mental health, designate technical coordinators for complex deliveries, reward technically minded people and create career paths for them, minimize swapping the staff through projects.

evaluation: None
Pros: I was a part of WSP in the Middle-East. I was a bit surprised that they had won some of the top tier projects in UAE. They pay salaries on time. You can book a lot of overtime even though do not work very hard, PM's do not monitor this. I haven't booked overtime to be honest, big mistake.
Cons: - They lay-off smart people without specific reason, even though the employee has not committed any errors or mistakes. When asked for the reason of redundancy, the management says 'It was just a cost cutting measure.' - Management has laid off employees who worked for a very short duration for no specific reason at all whilst retaining older staff who are responsible for not winning work (Most but not all) - Management provides false assurance to the staff that they are close to winning some great projects. In reality, they did not win most of them. - Retain useless staff who like to butter the management and literally do no positive contribution to the firm - HR policies are management friendly and not really favorable to the staff - HR folks do not have an answer to most queries of the redundant staff.  - After redundancies are made, HR sends false emails to redundant employees providing details of 'possible' jobs within wsp group. In reality, there are none! They just want to show that they care for the employees. - Personal Friendships mean more to the management that professionalism and hardwork. Employees who are close friends with managers in wsp middle east get away without any issues.  I personally do not recommend this company to any talented candidates. Please think many many times and take advise from your seniors in the industry before you take up a job here.
Advice to Management: Please do not hire staff if you do not have enough work! Why hire them and make them redundant within a short duration? Some of them come from poor and difficult backgrounds, please understand this.

Cons: Company is more concerned with optimizing profits and revenue vs. ensuring that their employees are satisfied. It's rather unfortunate that this is the case
Advice to Management: When you take care of your employees, they take care of you!

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: They gave me an opportunity to study a master degree in other subject. Allow me to work part time.  Some staff are technical excellence. Graduate can have a good opportunity to learn on first 1-2 years.
Cons: Management is so bad. Manager and director are only assign a valuable project to favouring employee and left the boring, messy project for other.  Difficult to gain experience for engineer qualification. Biased pay rise and promotion. Office politic problem.
Advice to Management: Set up a more transparency and fair policy to develop employees. Do not let only small group of people can be developed and let other behind

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook
Pros: WSP is very diverse and global.
Cons: Grown too big too quickly. I worked for WSP Environmental for 14 years, They were great to work for in the early yers with lots of highly professional and dynamic Directors who would alway spend time to teach others. By the time I left earlier this year they had completely lost sight of their maj aseet; their people and is now a maassive global cmpany ficussed on making the top 5% very rich and does not look after their staff.
Advice to Management: Look after your best people and stop your dreadful staff churn.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good working relationships between mid to junior level employees.
Cons: Below average salaries and annual salary increases which are not performance based and are less than inflation rates. Limited career progression. Minimal benefits which keep reducing. Patriachial management. No focus on staff retention or happiness.
Advice to Management: Re-focus on employees particularly mid level staff. Stop cutting funding for employee benefits and support programs. Stop rewarding high-level management with promotions while advising junior staff that promotion and salary increases were not provided due to ‘poor’ company performance despite having profit margins in excess of rival companies.

evaluation: Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good health plan, friday afternoon off, allows overtime, competent management, knowlegeable and dependable staff.
Cons: No budget for new material, constantly have to deny customers' requests, high pressure, no long term strategy from upper administration.
Advice to Management: Address common and recurrent IT issues with in-house training, mitigate case-by-case decisions on resources allocation by enforcing strong budgeting strategies, keep employees aware of budgeting strategies to avert rumors.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook

Advice to Management: Make it a more engaging place your juniors and listen to their suggestions.
